RATING: 6
Rating after 1 play.
Ingenious minimalist card game, but I wonder how much game is really there.

The more I play these micro games the more I wonder whether I'm actually playing a game at all. It seems like most of the time there is no game and that you are just playing for the random times when someone can actually make a reasonable deduction and you see if it works out.

RATING: 9
Very fun if your up for a quick little game. The rules are short, sweet, and to the point. I will say that the game is not very enjoyable if you only have 2 people playing, it is best played in groups of 4, and you can do a kind of 'tournament style' with 5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
So easy to learn, the game has some staying power in the meta-game (otherwise it falls over really fast). Drags super hard if people aren't judicious about their turns. The problem is since there isn't a particularly onerous amount of game here, I can't think of an occasion when I'd play this over something else; if I had 2p, wanted a small game, or I was short on time, I'd play Red7. If I wanted a quick social deduction game, I'd go for 3p/4p ONUW
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite 4 player games.  Whenever you find yourself in a group of 4, this game can always be pulled out.  Very easy to learn and teach.  Although it is mostly luck, the game plays very smoothly and each player feels he has a chance at winning.  Not your competitive game, get another one for that.  Very non-gamer friendly, but gamers will love to play it still.

UPDATE 2: Great game and very addicting. Lots of chance, but mad fun

RATING: 1
Player elimination + heavy luck factor + possibility of eliminating someone before they ever get their first turn = miserable excuse for a game.

Dat pasted theme tho.

Edit: Wow i am actually updating this from 1.5 to 1. Check out our last game with four players:
A plays Guard on first turn: "B, are you... x?"
B: "Yes."
Sits out for five minutes.
C plays Princess since, you know, you are Forced to sometimes. D asks: "Are you... Prince?" "Yes."
A and D exchange turns doing meaningless actions such as protecting their hand, looking at the opponent's, until one nabs the other with a Guard.
Winner: "I don't feel like i did anything; the cards played themselves."
WHAT A GREAT EXPERIENCE.

Love Letter, you're graduating to:
Literally not a game.

RATING: 9
Bluffing/Deduction games distilled to an extreme.  Wherein other games make you pull off some brilliant ploy over an hour while others watch(and there's drama and tension and everything in that), this game basically gets you to one of those moments VERY rapidly, and as soon as someone pulls off something clever, the round is over.  Almost never ends in a boring reveal.

RATING: 7.5
Innovative micro game that is like a handshake from modern game design.  The game is mostly a deduction/"take that" game, but the feeling of accusing someone and eliminating them on a hunch is ever so satisfying.  

There can be some wonky stuff that can happen and there isn't a lot of depth to this game at all, but the play time is so short that you really shouldn't expect an epic here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played this for the first time with my friends, despite having bought this for my step-sister for a holiday gift (never got a chance to play it with her yet, since we live half the US away from each other.)

The game was surprisingly fun, despite the fact that you are attempting to court the princess.  And it wasn't just fun because I handily won the first two rounds.  Other players did catch up, and in the round before the end of the game we were all tied.  It was great.  The final round concluded with two fast snipes using guards to correctly guess what other players held - it was impressive since for the entire rest of the game no one had used a guard to correctly guess someone on the first turn of gameplay.

All in all, I would play it again.  It was fast, complex enough to be interesting, with some nice deduction and not too much backstabbing.  (OK, I'm enjoying the backstabbing more... I sniped two player out of the game using guards - I had a really low hand but was able to hold my own until the end, it was great!)  

To continue with the sniping - I finally won a game by sniping both opponents in the last turn - using guards to protect the Princess I held in my hand.  It was great!  Especially since I was losing for the first half of the game... stealth to victory!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Such a surprisingly good little game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I rarely rate our own stuff, but this came from an outside designer, Seiji Kanai, and I feel ok rating it as a player.

This game is crazy fun. It's blindingly fast, most rounds over in minutes, and requires some good deductive skills without being overburdened with too much to track. For such a small game there is a ton of fun and can be played by just about anyone, gamer or non-gamer.

RATING: 6
This is, without a doubt, one of my favorite filler games (and from only 16 cards?!?!). It's definitely best with 3 or 4 players, though it can be a fun, very light filler with 2 as well.  It's highly addictive, and you can tell by how beat up my cards are.  However, it's totally worth it and more for only $10.  I will get this as a gift for others, and it makes a great stocking stuffer over the holidays .

RATING: 10
it is fantastic fun and light game. used to play for two hours non-stop.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love Letter was my first experience playing a "Micro Game" and as far as I can tell it has set the standard for such games. It plays like a sort of twisted "Go Fish" with romance. You are each trying to woo a princess by drawing and playing certain cards which each have certain powers that help you acheive the simple goal of being the last person standing. While you would think that player elimination makes the game less fun, it resolves quickly enough that down time is minimal. The goal is to score 3 points by either not being eliminated or by correctly guessing who has the princess card in their hand. I like this game. It is elegant and easy to play with gamers and casuals alike. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another instant classic in my house. You can teach it in 5 minutes, and while the game involves knocking players out, the rounds are so fast that nobody is ever out of the game for more than 45 seconds or so.

16 CARDS. This game is tiny, and yet, each card interacts with the others in unique and various ways. This game is simple but has immense replay value. It's a great game to introduce people to tabletop gaming, and simple enough that younger kids can still grasp it.

Highly, highly reccomend.

RATING: 10
I was very suspicious when I bought the game (I was not a big fan of the theme and name). But after few games I realized this is a game that everybody can enjoy. It's light, it's FUN, there is few elements of strategy and tactics but not too much to scare casual players. You can play it numerous time with the same pleasure and it's an excellent game that can bring expert and casual player at the same table and that means a lot to me. I tested it with different players and it worked all the time. This is one of the few games I rate 10

RATING: 5
Light, light, light filler that can go a tad longer than filler should.  Why so low?  Because in the game choice is an illusion.  To wit:

You hold in your hand two cards.  WHICH WILL YOU PLAY?!??  Well, if I play this one I lose so...  I PLAY THE OTHER!  And now who do I target with it...  ONE OF MY OPPONENTS!  And there's a small deduction element (which provides the ONLY hint of a whiff of anything resembling control) so I guess... KING!  Nope, go fish.  *sigh*  And my neighbor plays a card that takes me out of the round.

Thanks but no thanks.  Next game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is fun and we usually play it when we have some free time. It's amazing how you can have so much fun with only 16 cards.

The problem is that I sometimes feel that the game is a little too random and don't enjoy being quickly eliminated in plays of 4 people.

By the way, I hate having either the princess or the countess in my hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played this game just once, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

Love Letter is definitively one of the best micro-game I tried so far. Being someone who doesn't enjoy this kind of game, I have to say that I found Love Letter to be surprisingly interesting. It's still a pretty straight-forward game, but it has some elements of deduction, memory and bluffing, which spice things up just about enough.

That being said, it's still a micro-game... and I'm still not sold on these. I guess they could be a nice way to spend a few minutes, but I don't really see the point of playing something so shallow for those few minutes over just having a conversation. Therefore even if Love Letter might be one of the best micro-games out there, it still isn't my cup of tea. It's just barely OK.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Can't believe this is just a 16 card game. I must give it credit for that.

Having said that, this game feels more like an exercise of a few friends sitting down for a nice cup of tea and picking up a few cards and having some fun guessing those cards much like using ESP with hints and feeling good that you got it right. (Eventually, the card counting will tell)

There is no other game that plays similarly, and no other game that plays this way that badly either. It was enjoyable not because of the game, but the fun in looking at your opponents facial expression on guessing those cards.

It's a party game of sort, one that is good for a play or 2. UNO would have lasted more plays.

RATING: 9
Excellent jeu qui combine Déduction, Bluff et un peu de Stratégie. Cela se joue rapidement et je le recommande pour initier de nouveaux joueurs. Le jeu est assez léger, pas trop de cartes et ne dure pas trop  longtemps. Mais le temps que l'on y joue, c'est intense.

Il faut que votre lettre d'amour se rend a la princesse de deux manières. Soit vous avez la plus haute carte a la fin du tour, soit les lettres de vos adversaires ont été écartés. Et il faut gagner X fois pour remporter, tout dépend du nombre de joueur. Garder la princesse dans ses mains jusqu'à la fin du tour, c'est difficile.

RATING: 9.5
Played this loads of times already and I just got it! My group would rate it highly. The light elements of bluffing and deduction are fun, the portability is great, and due to how fast the game plays (another plus), the higher level of randomness doesn't feel punishing. Sure, you can get eliminated in turn one if you're unlucky, but a round probably won't last longer than a couple minutes. And it's often pretty funny how you lose. A game that plays quickly, goes well with light trash talking, and doesn't leave any hard feelings - terrific.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Letter is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. Your goal is to get your love letter into Princess Annette's hands while deflecting the letters from competing suitors. From a deck with only sixteen cards, each player starts with only one card in hand; one card is removed from play. On a turn, you draw one card, and play one card, trying to expose others and knock them from the game. Powerful cards lead to early gains, but make you a target. Rely on weaker cards for too long, however, and your letter may be tossed in the fire!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have fun for what it is and the time it takes. As a gamer, it can be kind of annoying to be taken out by some random action of another player before you've even had a chance to do anything. There's a lot of luck! But it moves fast and it's a fun filler that only lasts five minutes or less per hand.

RATING: 7
Thank you secret santa!

Players: 2-4
Time: 20 mins

Love Letter is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. Your goal is to get your love letter into Princess Annette's hands while deflecting the letters from competing suitors. From a deck with only sixteen cards, each player starts with only one card in hand; one card is removed from play. On a turn, you draw one card, and play one card, trying to expose others and knock them from the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A delightfully simple game, particularly considering how it makes use of only 16 cards.  The aim is to eliminate the other players and be the last man standing with the highest value card, played super-fast across several rounds.  Combine bluffing, deduction, a modest amount of strategy and quite a bit of luck, and you have a quick, light, and easily accessible filler that is highly portable and loads of fun.

While I own the original I also have a pimped "Princess Bride" version that is a joy to play, as the characters so nicely match the roles.

RATING: 4

It generates a good laugh in the first few rounds, once everyone understands the game play there's not much left. With less than 4 players, it becomes a guessing game. It may appeal for to fans of Dixit and other games alike, but there are so many more better party games.

RATING: 6
Not bad, but not that interesting either.  Frankly, I think Coup is the much more interesting "very short" game.  Coup has some adrenaline and laughter in it.  This is a fairly weak smile by comparison.

This game felt like the central mechanic was the "guard card" (with 5 cards) wherein you are trying guess another player's other card.  Thus, about 25% of the game was spent trying to guess another player's card.  The amusement of that mechanic, at least for me, wears off pretty quickly, whether deducible or not.  I do not want to try to guess your card...any more.

RATING: 8.5
I was very sceptical about that a game with only 16 cards and most of the time only one card on each players hand could be good. Wrong!
I really like this game and it has so often been played because it is so enjoyable.
I gave it already 3 times as a small present.
___________________
\_______GER_______/
Ich war etwas skeptisch, ob ein Spiel mit nur 16 Karten Spass machen kann. Aber nachdem ersten vollständigen Spiel zu zweit war mein Interesse geweckt. Bei den folgenden Spielen zu dritt war mir dann schenll deutlich geworden, dass in diesen 16 Karten eine Menge Spass stecken. Das Spiel ist sehr schnell erklärt, am Besten neue Mitspieler gar nicht lange mit Erklärungen quälen sondern einfach einmal offen vorspielen, danach kann es direkt losgehen. Ich bin mir sicher, das dieses Spiel häufiger auf den Tisch kommen wird. Dazu laden auch die schönen und grossen Karten ein.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I was very sceptical about that a game with only 16 cards and most of the time only one card on each players hand could be good. Wrong!
I really like this game and it has so often been played because it is so enjoyable.
I got this version by mistake. The cards of this US version are much smaler compared to the German cards. Therefore it is easier for traveling. However I prefer the larger German cards, if you have only one or two cards in your hand the cards should be at least large ;-)
I gave it (the German version) already 3 times as a small present.

RATING: 9
Love Letter is the epitome of minimalist design. It's only 16 cards. The gameplay is as simple as: draw 1 card, play 1 card. But for what it is, you get an unbelievable amount of game. Love Letter proves that sometimes less is more.

This is the original Japanese game with original art. Roles have different names with a slight difference of abilities from the US publication by AEG.

RATING: 2.5
I can't fathom what all the hype is about.  This is a complete non-game - the cards play themselves for awhile and eventually someone wins.  Every so often (maybe one round in five) there's an opportunity to make a simplistic, fourth-grade-level "deduction," but most of the time it's just thoroughly, profoundly random.

I gave this maybe half a dozen plays, really hoping things would click and I'd discover what it is that makes the game so popular.  Finally I concluded that while it's a clever concept, it's a terrible game.

RATING: 7
I appreciate this game a lot for pushing forward the microgame movement. Very good filler with simple rules and a little bit of deduction.

To me though, the game does feel like it's limited to just 16 cards, and there isn't much game outside of those cards.  If anyone deduces what your card is, it's just almost always in your best interest to play it right away, which just limits the decision making on your turn and limits the power of deductions.

RATING: 8.5
I've 'sold' this game as the most strategic card game you'll ever play with only 16 cards.  And in fact, there are really only 8 cards if duplicates are not counted.  So what makes it work so well?  It's super simple to teach.  Easy to grasp.  Highly portable.  And game play is quick.  You can play a short or full game as time permits.  Another game for the Every Gamer's Travel Pack(tm) collection.  Just not so sure that all the monopoly-like clones are doing the original any benefits though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Very nice filler. Only 16 playing cards, plus 4 summary cards, and 13 cubes make an excellent little game. Very easy concept. You have 1 card in your hand at all times, on the start of your turn you draw 1 more, then discard 1 of the 2 cards and execute it's text. When the round ends the player with the highest numbered card wins the round.
As cards are discarded you're able to deduce what players are holding in their hand. Supports only from 2 to 4 players unfortunately.

Ok, sometimes are terrible combinations: having the princess early in the round is always a problem, near the end of the round if you have the King and draw the Princess you probably are going to lose the round (unless they give you a Guard or a Prince), having 2 Baron cards is always risky (50% chance), when you discard the Countess you most likely have the Prince, King or Princess, especially later in the game, when you have the Baron and the Princess you have to play the Baron and if the other player has a high card you are pretty much exposed, (if the other player discards a 5, your chances of winning are drasticaly reduced - meaning you have a 6,7 or 8, if those haven't already been played/discarded).

since games can take around 10 rounds, I've played this around 10*20=200 game rounds. Which is a lot for a game with this complexity, since a round is essentially the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the easier games to learn, and rounds are very quick!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love letter is quite a strange little beast. It's bare bone and most of the times it plays you rather than being played. There's some deduction, but c'mon, what can you really do with a hand size of ONE plus the turn card?
And it is a game WITH PLAYER ELIMINATION? You must be kidding...

BUT.

This game is really more fun than it is supposed to be. And it's so quick that player elimination doesn't bother. And it is made with just 16 (with only 8 unique) cards and a handful of cubes...
Love Letter is truly showing what an ingenious designer can put together with essential materials and talent and inspiration!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Initial Impression: A nice filler game with minimal components. This is a quick deduction game that's as easy to teach as it is to play. The short playtime ensures that you can't stop after just one play.

10 Games: Still an enjoyable game. It's currently one of our 8 yr old daughter's favorites and she often requests it after dinner. Although the game has some "take that" to it, the rounds are so short and the promise of more guarantee that the players are not invested in any particular round. Eliminating a player doesn't result in any hard feelings or desires for revenge.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Raising my score from an 8 to a 9. The reason is not that this is the perfect game. The reason is that it has never failed to entertain any group of people I play it with. That's a 9 in my book.

Another UPDATE: I feel I should post another update to my feelings on this game. It is EASY to pull out and play. And it is easy to teach. I have pulled many friends into this game. I even finally got my wife to play. It is a hit every time. This game should be in every collection.

UPDATE: Finally got my daughter to play this several more times and now it's an easy one to pull of the shelf.  We both love how quickly it plays and the deductive component.

This score is based on a single play.  My 13-year-old got this game from a family member for her birthday.  I finally made her take it out and play it with me so she knows the rules the next time she has friends over.  She did her usual bored attitude while I read the rules and kept it up for the first six rounds.  Then something clicked.  She realized that this was a game of deductive logic and strategy and it's quick and simple.  That's her kind of game.  So, she excitedly managed to win the next three rounds in a row before I finally got her on a lucky guess with the guard.  She rated it a 6, but I think once she has taught it to some friends and played it a few more times, that score will go up closer to a 7.  It's nothing special, but it is very portable and extremely easy to learn if you just jump in and try a few rounds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Isn't it remarkable what a good designer can do with only 16 cards. This game had me hooked from the very beginning, because it gives you that nice feel of reading your opponents, and plays fast. In some odd way it reminds me of We Didn't Playtest This At All because with the play of a single card someone could easily be eliminated. This keeps the game from taking long, and definitely gives you that "let's play again" feel. I particularly like that there can be some deduction as you watch what cards have been played, and figure out what cards might be remaining in your opponents' hands. I almost wish they added a few more cards in order to make it work for more players. That could be my biggest nitpick with this game, because it feels like one of those fun light games that I'd like to bring out even with a party gaming group, but it only plays up to 4. Still, that's such a minor complaint for a good game.  It won't necessarily become a classic that people are playing for generations, but it is certainly a good, solid title that I will keep in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.75
I really enjoy this little game for what it is. I think it shines best at 4 players, particularly if each player considers some higher level strategy. There is a surprising amount of depth in that deck of 16 cards for those who look. It becomes less enjoyable playing with people who don't want to work their brains a bit and strategize. They can come off feeling "meh" about the whole experience. Sometimes luck can play an overbearing factor in ones victory or loss, but each round is lightning fast enough that elements of luck don't detract from the fun.

RATING: 9
After playing Love Letter too many times I got convinced it isn’t that bad people don’t write love letters anymore: now I only complain they didn’t stop earlier. (November 2012)

[b]Update I[/b] - As it shows through my original comment, my first contact with Love Letter was terrific: it was explained badly and the following games were even worse, devoid of any fun.

Yet, after playing it massively with a suitable group of light-hearted gamers, Love Letter got better and better: now it’s showing its true nature, that of the good and light filler packed with fun and laughter it was meant to be upfront.
Hence in December 2012 I raised my rating from 3 to 7.

[b]Update II[/b] - Lots of loud fun in just sixteen cards: Love Letter is such a little gem!
Thus, after (massively) playing it further, in November 2013 I raised my rating from 7 to 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
40 plays: 

A real gem of a super light, casual game. Very fast to learn. Only a tiny bit of strategy involved, and playable with no strategy at all, so it scales to all ages.

Theme is delightful, if a bit clunky. I do wish cards had been added which included real love letters, just to hold in your hand next to your one card to clarify that that card indicates who currently holds your love letter, rather than who "you" are. 

It does feel at times like several turns will go by without requiring very interesting decisions. And skilled gamers will find it basically a "solved" game like tic-tac-toe. But the simplicity, quickness of play and pleasant theme make it a good casual game for all ages.

I understand that gamers who play this may be disappointed; there's not much of a game here. But it has a je-ne-sais-quoi that make it continue to compel us to play it and introduce it to others.

It should be mentioned that the art is just a tiny bit risqué, which is a surprising decision. But my daughters don't seem to have noticed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Love Letter is a nice gateway game that introduces players to deduction mechanics without paralysis. Its easy to teach and doesn't overwhelm players with vast decision making.  

Despite my opinion that this is a good gateway, I do not think that it is a good filler. First to four affection cubes in a four-player game is quite long and even longer given the inevitable "king of the hill" gameplay. 

After you play a few rounds and everyone has a few cubes, you just kind of want the repetitiveness to be over. I don't know why it has a 20 minute playing time.

Very quick game, but very light on decision making. I like the deduction element of this game, as it involves a slight social aspect. It also has the potential for cheating which is a design flaw, but this should not be an issue for playing with people you trust. It is surprising that they managed to fit a decent little game into so few components.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
Juego de deducción. Hay 16 cartas numeradas. 5 con el 1, 3 con el 2, tres con el 4, dos con el 5, 6, 6 y 8. Cada carta permite hacer ciertas acciones con otros jugadores, o interactúa con la otra carta que tenga el jugador. El juego consiste en no ser eliminado y sobrevivir con la carta de mayor valor. Sencillito a tope, pero probablemente resultón para 5 o 6 jugadores.

En mi colección, en versión juego de tronos, por cortesía de mazmaz, desde el 27/12/2013.

RATING: 6
Getting my wife to play games with me is a very delicate thing and there are two occasions where I have done myself an injustice. The first was involving her in a five-player game of Mousquetaires du Roy, the second was getting her to play a few quick rounds of Love Letter with me before we had company over one day last year. It was a disaster, she hated it. She looked up at me and said "what's the point?" and then she said, I probably hate this more than that Musketeers game you made me play. She's very finicky and I had built up a solid foundation with games like Jaipur, Mr. Jack and Boss Monster; but this 2-player Love Letter episode may have done irreparable damage. I've played it once with four and seen it played with four as well and think it's a solid, quick little game; but avoid the 2p experience!

RATING: 8
Delicious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rated for balance of cards and length of play. Only 15 cards to play to complete a round, meaning only 3 or 4 decisions per round at most if you are not eliminated. That is not a negative, because 4 rounds (4 player) are required to win the luck factor is reduced. Bluffing can help to protect your hand, and the prevalence of Guards (5) and the 2 Priests help to weed out the stronger characters. The most interesting game out there, with the least components. Nicely done, and popular with all gamer types. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my go-to games when I either don't have space or have people at my house who don't play games.

It's simple enough that pretty much anyone can play it. I love the bluffing element and the double guessing that goes into it too. It's fun watching the lightbulb turn on for people after the first couple hands.

I personally think the theme is brilliant because of how silly and girly it is. My guy friends usually turn their nose up at it the first time they play and then the next time they come over are saying "Let's play that princess game!"

This is one of the best gaming purchases I've ever made...go buy it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
   A super quick, portable, easy-to-teach game with just enough intrigue to captivate (ideally) 3 or 4 players.  There are only 16 cards, so it's probably not necessary to leave all played cards exposed - but it's a good idea to do so if you're playing with newer or younger players.

   We also have Letters to Santa, which offers a bit of seasonal fun - and I have seen a few re-theme variants; but having played Lost Legacy, I prefer it over Love Letter.

Can't decide which is worst, Love Letter or Coup.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
At first glance, [b]Love Letter[/b] looks too simple.  There are only sixteen cards in the deck.  The game is played until one player wins a set number of rounds (depending on the number of players).  A player wins a round by possessing the highest numbered card at the end of the round, or by knocking out all his opponents (more likely).

LL is a perfect balance of logical deduction and luck.  I suspect, however, that it may become a little repetitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Love Letter loses a lot of it's appeal as a 2 player game. In fact, I'd say don't play it if you only have 2 players, and there are plenty of other and better games for 2 players out there.

As a 3 or 4 player game I like the very simplistic design of Love Letter, the games are so fast that even when you're bumped out of a round it's not a big deal. May annoy players who get bumped more than once though. I really enjoy it with the max amount of players. I would recommend this because of its simplicity and I believe it would be a very easy game to get people to play. It makes a great gateway game, I feel.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Surprisingly fun for a game of just 16 cards.  It plays quickly and is easy to learn--both nice features.  However, I think once you move up the learning curve, a lot of the games start to feel the same, so I'm not sure about replayability.  

A comment on the player number polls:  I agree the game is best for 3-4, but I don't understand why 60% of people say the 2 player game is "not recommended."  It's still quite fun -- at least, it is not THAT inferior to the 3-4p game.

RATING: 7
This game is not only just a filler game. Love Letter is designed to be a very simple game that involves luck and deduction. The player needs to manage his hand properly in order not to get eliminated. The simplicity will be really friendly for the newcomers. I usually play this game with those who have their first step into board gaming. It has depth and thematically it leaves the good impression of the Renaissance era.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't get this one. Well, OK, I get that it's a really short, really simple time-killer that you can play with kids, and the idea of delivering love letters is nice. But as a game it's pretty trivial, very random, the setting is thinly drawn, and I want games that are going to do more than fill time. Not sure how or why it set the world on fire.

I've enjoyed this more if you play it with a memory element, covering over previously-played cards. Then at least there is a modicum of skill involved (memory being a skill), and it adds a little tension. The designer does explicitly says all previously-played cards should be visible, but I think he's wrong on that. With totally open information it's pretty trivial (for adults anyway) and a bit tedious.

RATING: 3
I'm really not a fan of bluffing or deduction, so this game just plain isn't targeted at me.  I can see why it would be appealing to a lot of people though, as it would be a great quick filler if you're into the mechanics.

For me personally, any amount of bluffing in a game just feels more like guesswork, and deduction generally requires too much memory for my tastes, even if it's a small amount of memory.

While the game is super quick, I'd rather just spend the time doing nothing.  Most people will probably like Love Letter more than I do though!

RATING: 6
As with bowling, I tire of this game after 3 rounds.  Stick to the original rules, not the AEG ones.  If you want a little more treachery, play until someone scores 2 or 3 tokens.  For longer games stick to AEG's scoring suggestion.  If everyone is playing deductively, they will just knock down the person likely to win early on causing the tokens to be distributed evenly.

RATING: 9.7
Genius at work...16 cards...never has so much been done with so little.  I also love how the game evolves...for instance, if you always play a 3 with a high card, you give too much information...eventually, you start taking more risks hoping for the opponent to have a 1.  Standard play is developed than deconstructed to meta play then eventually back to a new standard play, etc.

RATING: 8
Love Letter is light, wonderful filler.

It plays quickly, eliminates players, but does not keep them sitting on the sidelines for long, and keeps players guessing as to who is closest to the Princess.

I'll play it just about any time.

2-4 Players = Love Letter

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
With simple draw-one-play-one mechanics, it's a good time-filler to have around. Once you've played a few times it's always the same, and gets old quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There need to be more games with this quality of strategy that can be played in under 30 minutes. Unfortunately, it seems that designers now think that in order for a game to appeal to strategy players, it has to last at least 2 hours. Not true.

Love letter is good. It's quick, fun, and requires some thought and bluff. But I can't for the life of me understand how it rates more highly than Coup City State on BGG. The latter seems to play differently every time, offers far more bluffing, strategy, subterfuge and decision making than Love Letter. After playing several times, it becomes clear that there isn't much variety in how the game plays out.

There is an indisputable element of luck in this game, but it is one that I can happily handle on account of the fact that it balances between players, and since rounds last only a couple of minutes, a stroke of bad luck is quickly brushed aside. Nevertheless, hitting the bad luck of ending the round by drawing the unwinnable King/Princess combo is, to my mind, a bit of a design flaw.

It's a nice game. It's a fast game. It's a game that brings smiles AND satisfies the serious strategic gamer in me. But it's not Coup.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When I hear the term "microgame," I basically think of Coup and Love Letter. Now having played both, I give the slight nod to Coup for entertainment value.

Love Letter is fairly impressive for creating a game with only 16 cards, but if I'm honest about the game experience, it's pleasant enough but takes up enough time that I'd rather be playing something else. I had hoped that it would involve more deduction. Instead, in too many rounds, someone can get shafted by an unfortunate draw, and the whole thing feels just a little bit too random.

Update: traded this one away. One play was enough for me to know that I've got better games to play in the time it takes to play this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The ultimate filler game, everyone has 1 card and your turn you draw a card then play a card and hope to not be eliminated. It plays really fast, but I can't help but think of other micro games that are better than this. Khmer/Elements if you have 2 people, Red7 with more, and also some of the other small dice games like Qwixx or Bang Dice. For how short it is I don't mind playing it, but bluffing is not fun to me so it becomes more an activity to me.

RATING: 9

You really need to pay attention to every card play but you also need to watch for other clues as well (comments, facial expressions, etc.).  

Amazing that a 16 card deck could pack so much punch.

Great for gamers and non-gamers.

One of my favorite games to play.

Absolutely love this game. It is a firm family favourite, and we are still discovering certain card combinations that can win or lose you the round: the phrase 'double Baron' has entered our family's lexicon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I can't think of any game that went from me liking it to disliking it more than Love Letter. At first I loved how easy it was to teach, how portable it was (the tuckbox and paper tokens I made made it ultra portable), and how approachable it was for non-gamers.

Now the game just feels like it plays itself since there's never difficult decisions to make, and I've found other portable games that I find more enjoyable and/or strategic. Also, the theme just doesn't make any sense. Reading the intro in a rulebook should enhance a game, not add confusion. I still find the art on the Kanai version pleasing though.

I've seen people claim Love Letter is their favorite / the best game of all time and that really baffles me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I'm not sure if this game is great, or if I'm just flabbergasted that someone would release a game that only consists of only 8 different cards, 16 cards total (and a few cubes). This game has player elimination, even before they have any choices, but it's fast enough that it seems ok to me. But I sort of suspect that after a little time this will fade fast, and only be pulled out as a novelty, and when we really only have 15 minutes. Shame that it only scales to 4. 

Update: still going strong. Gets requested. Especially by my non-gaming daughter. This is perhaps a gateway game to gateway games.

Update: Ok, raising rating to 8. It almost feels silly to rate such a minimal game an 8.

This is possibly the only game I own where the packaging costs more to manufacture than the contents.

I prefer a merge of the Japon/AEG rules: Countess rules from AEG, Handmaid rules from Japon (may be targeted, but nothing happens).

RATING: 9.25
This game gets a lot of flack for being so simple, with such a simple mechanic, but simply put... it's fun! I have never NOT had a blast playing this game, it can be taught in less than 2 minutes, and is incredibly portable. 
While all the different themes for it that are being released are unnecessary, it is still a lot of fun and deserves all the attention it has received.

RATING: 8
This small filler (16 cards) is addictive. One game
is not enough. On our first try we ended up playing
for over 90 minutes. This just grabbed us and we couldn`t
stop playing. This will be added to my permanent collection of games I always take with me in any family
situation. Have made a miniature version measuring 65mmx44mm (Inkl.mini hearts) , so its a perfect fit even in my wallet.Every true gamer should have this on them.
This designer will be checked for other nuggets of gold.
Love pulling people into the hobby with such simple and
elegant games. My heart just made a leap. Sigh!!!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
How can a game with so few cards be so much fun?  No need to sit and puzzle over it, just dive into this clever game with ridiculously simple rules.  Draw a card, discard a card, always keeping one in your hand.  The discarded one has an associated action which helps you try to ferret out your opponent's identities and get them eliminated from the game.

If you go for light, simple games that are fun with a group, then this is a must-have.  I know I'll be trying to grab a copy at the first opportunity!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
MULTIPLAYER:

RATING: 8
Love letter is a fun little pocket game. It is great to get people that are entirely new to gaming on to something other than standard playing cards. a gateway to a gateway game. Very few cards and simple rules, easy to play with kids and fun every time I play it. I give it an 8 because there it becomes repetitive after a single play through so not one I would play over and over the same night, however, works fantastically as a filler game or a quick not too thinky game to play on the couch while you are watching a movie or something.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
I'm a big fan of bluffing games and this one combines the good parts from Citadels(hidden characters with different powers) with a much shorter play time because of the lack of construction cards(usually around 10-15 mins).

I played it with a lot of groups(gamers and non-gamers) and it caught on rapidly, up to the point where gaming sessions got 1 hour longer because people wanted to play more than 1 game round.

The down side is that it's only supports 4 players, would have proffered 5 or 6 as it is a party game.

RATING: 6
Interesting how you can make a playable game with only 16 card. It can be fun, but you can't take it too serious - very often you will have feeling you can simply throw a dice to determine the winner of the game instead of playing it :o) But if you have 10 minutes of spare time and you want to play a game, there probably aren't much better choices.

RATING: 6
Components: Good graphic design; pleasant, thematic art; readable rules.

Experience: With two players, doesn't really seem to work. Not very much deduction; lots of guessing; mostly obvious what to do.

With three players, a bit more going on, trying to survive while other players duke it out. A bit more deduction.

First Played: 2013-04-09
Last Played: 2015-03-27
Plays (4):

RATING: 8
Very fast. Very easy to learn. Simple. Elegant. Highly portable. Appeals to almost any gamer with a pulse. Great artwork. Superb value for money. 

And the play? Utterly wildly delightful and fun. Perfect balance and blending of deceit, bluffing and luck. Laughter-filled moments. What a superb gem of a game. 

Perhaps the most perfectly designed small/filler game I've ever played (though For Sale! comes pretty close).

RATING: 4
Deep strategy with tons of number crunching and countless paths to victory.

...or not.

This game is simple.  I mean S-I-M-P-L-E simple.  You have two options each turn, and you choose one of those options.  Sometimes you are guessing blindly, and sometimes you have a little more information and are able to play tactically.  But most of the time, you are just making your best educated guess (and sometimes you're just plain guessing).  But who cares?  The game is fun, quick, and playable by anyone, meaning that even non-gamers can get in on the action.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Letter is a small game that packs a lot of punch. While suitable for two, it really shines with 3-4 players. I have had nothing but positive remarks when this game has hit the table.

What really sets this game apart is how easy it is to pick up by non-players. After only one round, everyone at the table understood everything they needed to enjoy the rest of the game, and eagerly awaited their next move. It can be unfortunate when one person gets kicked out of a round without getting to do anything because an opponent wins a showdown against a first-move Baron, but the rounds are so fast that no one gets knocked out for long.

For such a small and portable game, there is a LOT of gameplay here.

That said, the gameplay is not novel enough to warrant limitless play-throughs, as the number of player options that can occur are very limited. Compare this with Coup (another 15-card microgame), which adds a bluffing mechanic that makes rounds significantly more strategy-based. So, Love Letter can get repetitive if played too much, unlike more social/strategy-based games that you can go back to endlessly, but I don't think it needs to be that type of game.

Love Letter is a perfect game for a casual get-together with friends, busting it out every once and a while.

★★★★★★★★☆☆ 8/10

RATING: 7
Pros: Neat art and a decent amount of decision space for the size of the game. Small element of bluffing. Great to introduce newbies to gaming. Fast playing and easy to transport.

Cons: So many editions to choose from.

Quirky theme. Quick filler card game with a small bit of deduction. Replayability comes from not playing this too often. With the premium edition, it enters true party game status and trades off ease of teaching and quickness of play for larger player count and more card effects. Still one of the best filler games in existence.

2014
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
[April 2017 - 8.8] Fine-tuning the rankings. This is still a go-to game for me when there's 10 minutes at the beginning of game night or as casual game in a bar, so it remains pretty high in my rankings despite its simplicity.

[February 2015 - 9.0]
Still hanging strong for me, even though it slipped a notch. Some other short games (such as For Sale) have given it competition in my collection, but Love Letter is still the game I pull out when time and space are an issue, and people like it a lot. Again, such a great game for so few cards.

[July 2014 - 9.1]
Love Letter -- perhaps purposely so -- is one of those games where you're playing at a bar and people come up to ask what you're playing.  "Uh, you say with some hesitation and slight embarrassment, it's called 'Love Letter' ... and look at this luxurious red bag it comes in!" No wonder the publishers are coming out with different themed versions.  Joking aside, Love Letter is the perfect game for any downtime at the bar, the airport, or while waiting at the DMV. A few plays in and most everyone has a good chance to win. I'll be interested to see if they ever expand it with new cards to the base set of 16. I can't decide if that would improve the game or ruin it.

RATING: 6
Nice lightweight game played using only a few cards, which represent roles a player can take on.  When the game lets you do so, you can occasionally have some interesting bluff related decisions to make.  But just as often the game forces your hand, and have no choice.  Any time you have the princess card, you have no choice, for instance.  Toward the end that can just mean you lose.  Plus, there are the guard cards, which may mean loss anyway.  So in the end it just felt very chaotic and random, things I wouldn't normally enjoy.  That it only took fifteen minutes redeemed it somewhat.

RATING: 8
So far I have only played this as a 2 player with my wife but I very much enjoy the game and the concept.  The game was super simple to pick up and understand and the version we got came with customized card sleeves which was a nice touch.  Gameplay is fast and easy to learn (we put all the cards in the protectors, read through the rules, set the game up, and played to completion in less than an hour).  I could also see how playing with numerous people could definitely increase the intensity of the game.  Will definitely be playing again!  

Only downsides I would say are that at times the game is entirely luck based and there are situations where a round is impossible to win which can make those rounds feel unbalanced, but such is life right?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A quick little filler. Explain it in a minute, start playing, takes about half an hour or less.

Who?
Basically, this game is very light and thus aims at families or non-gamers. However, it is also great to play this as a finisher for an otherwise deeper gaming night.

What? 
Guess your opponents' cards and thus get them (the opponents) out of play. Last man standing gets a victory point. Whoever is the first to have a predetermined amount of victory points wins the game.

Fun
As a two-player game, this is really rather bland. However, four players of the right kind make this really hilarious. 

Quality of components
High. The art is outstanding, the cards themselves are made out of heavy card stock and seem very robust.

Altogether, I rate this 7.5, because, while light, this game doesn't overstay its welcome and produces laughs while playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The princess is upset.  Players are suitors, trying to get the palace staff to deliver your consoling love letter to the princess.  Quirky Japanese game, played with a deck of sixteen cards.  Each card is numbered between 1 (Guard) and 8 (Princess).  There are multiple copies of several cards.  One card is dealt out of the round, face down, and one card is dealt to each player - this is their hand.  On their turn, the player draws a card, adds it to their hand, then discards one of their two cards.  The discarded card must be actioned.  Each card's action interacts with the other players in some way - the Guard's action names another player and a character, knocking that player out of the round if they deduce the character correctly.  To win a round, you have to be the last one standing, or hold the highest value card when the round ends.  To win the game, you have to win a pre-determined number of rounds.  Totally insane, more bluff and luck than tactical, but works very well as a ten minute filler.  Better with 3 or 4, but still fun with 2 players.  Great stocking stuffer for Xmas.

Having now played several games of the Japanese version, I think the Japanese rules are better and make for a more interesting game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
a wonderful, simple, deep filler (betcha never though you'd hear that about a filler). Actually a very interesting game of bluff with some small, but decisive, decisions. Easy to teach, easy to pick up but with lots of game to it.
While a full game usually lasts about 15 minutes, you'll most probably play more than one. Kind of like good popcorn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I am not a fan of card games but seeing so many positive reviews on this one it made me wonder. I did not regret for acquiring this small card game. It can be played with up to 4 players and the whole deck consists of 16 cards!! Each card has special abilities and poses restriction to others. After a few hands everyone knows by heart all cards and the game becomes something of a poker game. Is you adversary bluffing or is he going for the long shot (give his intimate letter to the princess?) There is a 50% chance that he holds that specific card or has it the guy next to me? Very fun and ingenious small game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In a general sense, a game that I believe is almost perfect.  There are longer, better, prettier, more strategic and more fun games to play.  But for the price, difficulty level, portability and accessibility you will never have more fun with a game.  This is one of the easiest games to play.  To newcomers, the instructions are as simple as "Draw a card, Play a card, Do what the card says."  The strategy gets deeper (not too much more), but the real fun comes in trying to read the other players and the mind games involved both externally and internally which give the game so much replayability.  This game includes just a small deck of cards and a few tokens, as well as a nice velveteen satchel if you buy the right version, and with so few components it can be played almost anywhere.  Play a few rounds between bigger games to cool down or involve more people.  Play a few rounds while you are waiting for your sushi to arrive at a restaurant.  Play a few rounds with your six year old daughter instead of an hour and a half of trouble.  This game has universal appeal and such elegant gameplay that I have to include it in my top 10.

RATING: 8
Very quick and clever little Japanese filler that might only take 10 minutes to play, using a deck of 16 cards.   That’s a pretty constrained design space!   You are trying to be the last player left with a card in hand, and the higher the better....or the last person left in the hand.  It boils down to bluffing, deduction and card-counting, which at this scale, works really well.   Pleasantly surprised.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Quick. Fast. Easy-to-Learn. Simple.
This simple game consisting of 16 cards is surprisingly fun and interesting. Great  game to throw in your bag/backpack and play with friends out camping, at dinner, or just to kill time. On your turn you simply draw a card and discard a card. The card you discard is the action you get to do. Last man standing wins! Who's who? Why did they play that? Did the Princess say that she liked me?... Here, can you give this to her? Haven't played?, go pick it up! It's only $10 and has many different iterations/themes. It is definitely worth the $10.

RATING: 7
Every time I play I can never decide if I like the game or not. I have fun...Sort of. I feel like I'm playing a game...Sort of. It feels a bit like college when a group of us would play Spades and Gin all the time. It because a way to pass the time and having played so often the game played itself because the best moves (the moves to minimize risk and luck in other words) were second nature. So I play Love Letter in that mindset in that I'm not really thinking about the game. I won't get rid of it, but I also don't celebrate it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'm still surprised when I come across non-gamers who've never heard of this tiny hit, when you'd be hard-pressed to find a game who hasn't. A must for most collections, Love Letter is a simple, quick and fun game, consisting only of a small deck of cards.

While not particularly deep or mentally stimulating, the gameplay is quick enough to keep you involved, and the deducing a wise decision is still fun. While a very random game, full of wild guesses and nonsense, it's appealing nature and easy of transport make it a must for most collections.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I’ve been bringing out this game for years as an opener during game meets and it always goes over so well.  Holding up so well, for so long, year after year, it is a classic and perfect for non-gamers to have a good time sitting right alongside seasoned veteran gamers.  It is so easy for non-gamers to pick up the rules quickly and everyone really has a good time.  With only sixteen cards and only eight types of characters, it is streamlined well balanced, and a work of genius.   
The only possible caveat with the game is you really do need EXACTLY four people to play it well.  Playing with three people is not as good, and it really isn’t possible with two people despite what the rules say.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.78
Amazingly fun card game which is ingenious in its simplicity. It has only 16 cards but the game is rarely the same. 
Whoever has a card closest to a princess at the end of the game or, more commonly, who eliminates other competitors has won the round and, possibly, the heart of the princess.
Kanai designed truly remarkable, fast card game with a cute theme.

[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Texas Holdem with a theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is another card game (like Coup) where you have a very small amount of cards used to a really quick game.  The premise is simple: Each player has a card in their hand. At the start of your turn you draw a card, hope you're not immediately eliminated and then choose one of your two cards to discard if you haven't been eliminated.  The card you discard activates it's ability.  You keep doing this until all but one player is eliminated or the last card is taken from the deck.  If the deck runs out, the player with the highest valued card is the winner.  It's an ok filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A simplistic social deduction / card counting game played with only 16 cards.  There's not always that much you can do on your turn due to your small hand of 2 cards, and so if you want to card count and outguess which card your opponents have, this is for you. 

2 player doesn't work that well and I thought this was more of a conceptual game mechanic than an actual 'game'.  OK, it's fun, but wears out its welcome at the end, after several rounds of guessing and counting, so I'm not sure how much replayability this would have in the long run - especially as opponents' play styles become known and patternistic.  Probably won't hold the attention of the so-called 'serious gamer' beyond 1 or 2 initial games and seemingly milked to death by designer for all sorts of inane re-themes.

RATING: 10
Gives you the biggest bang for volume. This alone is why I'm giving it a 10/10.

Tiny pocket filled with a few cards and a few tokens, but enough suspense to ruin friendships. Very high replay-ability.

Funny story - my sister was introduced to a guy (not by me) who came over to meet us at a cafe, and I suggested that we play this game. He was anal about following every single rule, and won the game. Super smug about it, then left right after. Right after he left, sister said: "Wait, how did he win? What about *this* rule?". He was such a stickler for rules that we knew it wasn't an accident. We still laugh about it every time we bring this game out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[3 plays] This game is so simple and minimal you'd think it would be really easy to pick up and get into. It's probably very easy to learn if you're all learning together, but it can be more difficult than you'd think to jump in with experienced players. Because there's so little to the game (not meant as an insult), after playing a bit you know all the cards inside out, and can easily card-count and make swift deductions based on what people do. So for the new player, while you're still at the level of sitting there looking at the player aid trying to figure out what the card you just drew does, it's like stuff is moving lightning fast at a higher level. 
This also seems like a shorter game than it really is. That's true of most games that use this sort of "first to win X rounds wins the game" scoring; there's a big difference in how long it takes if one person wins X in a row, vs. if every player gets to X-1 first. And number of players also makes a difference. So each round of the game remains quick, but the game itself can take longer than you'd think.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In the wake of the queen's arrest, all the eligible young men of Tempest (and many not so young) seek to woo Princess Aneette. Unfortunately, she has locked herself in the palace, and everyone must rely on those within the palace to bring their romantic letters to her. Will yours reached her first? Love Letter is a game of risk, deduction, and luck, for 2-4 players. Get your love letter into Princess Annette's hands while keeping other players' letters away. Powerful cards lead to early gains, but make you a target. Rely on weaker cards for too long and your letter may be tossed in the fire! Japanese game designer Seiji Kanai features only 16 cards but hours of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is better with 4 players than 2 players.  With 2 players it is a lot of luck.  When 4 players are involved, there is much more logic and bluffing involved since the action cards only target one other opponent.

There's definitely more strategy and card counting involved with 4 players.  But you have fewer turns so you need to make the most out of your turn to deduce as much as you can.  Sometimes you can't learn anything about other players on your turn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love Letter is a nice light game with an equal balance of strategy, luck and deduction; for 16 cards this game can become quite engrossing!

The rules are simple, short and very clear, any clarification needed is covered in the rules so is no confusion.

The only, truly bad thing I can say about this game is that it is possible to be knocked out of a round before a player has their turn; if this happens a few turns sequentially it can become a little frustrating.

Given the very social and light-hearted nature of the game it makes me wish the game supported up to 5 or 6 players.

Love Letter is solid, light game with enough different flavoured versions to appeal to both for gamers and non-gamers alike.

A mandatory gateway game in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
No recorded plays here, but I have played in the past.

Obnoxious game that claims to be a social deduction game, but has the least in any such game I've ever seen.  I would rather play Win, Lose, or Banana than this.  I would rather play Coin Age.  I would rather play the first hand of Race for the Galaxy.  I would literally play almost anything other than this non-game of bullshit statistics.

EDIT: I finally won. I take everything back. This game is the best.

RATING: 8
Azt kell mondjam, ez egy rettenetesen élvezetes játék! Sokszor olvastam már, de el igazán nem hittem, hogy ennyi lapból egy izgalmas, élvezetes parti/családi játékot lehet összehozni. De, lehet! Vicces, feszült, egyszerű. Gonosz kis játék, de a családbarát jellege megmarad, mert ha ki is esik valaki, néhány perc múlva következik az újabb kör. Gyorsnak azért nem mondanám, mert bár egy kör gyorsan lemegy, de az összegyűjtendő kegyjelzők miatt, azért el tud húzódni egy játék. Mondjuk ez egyáltalán nem hátrány. Az ár/érték arány egy érdekes dolog: mit is takar pontosan? A megvásárolt „anyagot”, vagy a megvásárolt élvezetfaktort? Ha az előbbit, akkor rossz ez az arány. Viszont, ha az utóbbit, akkor több mint rendben van. Ki-ki döntse el maga. Számomra az élvezeti faktor megvan, az anyagminőség viszont hagy kívánnivalót maga után. Sőt! Egyenesen botrányos a minősége! Harmadik (!!!) játékunk után elkezdett leválni a kártyák hátlapja. Kártyavédő vásárlása szükséges a játékkal együtt! Amennyiben az anyagiaktól eltekintünk, akkor egy kötelező vételű társasról beszélünk!

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played with: 4.

Love Letter is my current (12/2/16) favorite quick style card game.  It's fast, it requires a bit of luck, strategy and patience.  The "story" the game gives you is boring and does not do this title justice, as the game is quick and exciting.  The description make it look like an erotic novel with letters being passed around.

Players keep a card in hand, and then draw a card from the middle.  They must then discard/play one of their two cards in hands before the action moves to the next player.  These cards have actions that affect the other players in different ways.   

Short and sweet, pick this game up in any of its other flavors if you're not crazy about the art.  Or just grab it and enjoy a very fun quick style game that anyone should find fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a very simple, tight card game. It's a great "filler" game because you can finish a hand in just a couple of minutes, and a game in perhaps 20-30 minutes. I've played this while waiting in line for the movies, after being eliminated from a longer boardgame, while waiting for other gamers to show up for game day, etc. It's better when you add a dash of role-playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's amazing how much of a game you can create from a set of just 16 cards - 5 of which are identical to each other.  There may not be a ton of real decisions to make, but it's a cute, quick bluffing game that's perfect for pulling out in places where you have a few minutes and not much room. The decision each turn is just which of two cards you hold in your hand to play - but there's enough variety in what the cards do to keep things interesting. I'm very glad to have a copy in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I have to say that I really do not like this game.  I forced my husband and children to play it with me just to see if I was missing some fantastic aspect of the game.   But no,  as far as my family is concerned, this game is just random and dull with very few choices to take.  It seem like there is very little going on until the last 2 or 3 cards, and by then which card a player has is quite easy to guess.  With just two cards to choose from each turn, it feels like the game almost plays you.   The first few turns are just a shot in the dark, usually, with a guard card.  If the player is lucky enough to guess correctly, the other player is out without even getting to play!  Then there is the handmaid  card which  just feels like a skipped turn.   I must say that I actually owned the Hobbit version, but, I do not want to turn anyone off that version if they like the Love Letter game in general.  I really just to not like the general game play of Love Letter  no matter what the theme.   For hidden role games I would rather play and would recommend Bang the Dice Game,  Lost Temple, or Mission Red Planet.

If you haven't played this you should probably give it a try. But don't buy.

RATING: 1
Some cute bluffing and induction exists in this simple ruleset and can hardly outstay its welcome. AEG's insistence that multiple games be played in a row to determine the winner is bothersome, even if the Countess is a marked improvement over the Japanese version's Wizard.

Unfortunately, a short perusal of the game's limited set of cards shows how restrained any sort of strategy is. Most available hands necessarily pigeonhole players into particular decisions. The game is so short and so brainless as to be a purely pointless pastime.

(3 plays)
First Impression: 2

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was bummed to learn that, despite what the AEG website says, does not use the English rules from the Tempest edition with the Japanese art.  Instead, it is the exact japanese edition, translated. 

The japanese rules are different for #7.  In the AEG Tempest edition, you simply have to play #7 if you have the Prince or King in your hand. In the original Japanese rules, if your card total equals 12 or more, you lose. This means that simply drawing a card, even on your first turn, can cause you to lose the game. 

The Tempest rule is far superior, because you can use some strategy in playing #7 to bluff that you have the 5 or 6 in your hand. Meanwhile, the Japanese rules make holding onto the 5, 6, or 8 a death sentence. There's no hedging your bets on whether or not to hold onto a high card or to play it, because if you hold onto it there's a good chance you'll draw a card and lose, and there's nothing you can do about it.

Still, it's a fun game, but the Tempest rules are better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very quick, simple, but fun game. Not a ton of strategy, but there's enough to make it interesting as a good filler game. 

See my Kenai Factory edition comment for my comparison of the two editions.

RATING: 4
I love it for its stupidity and simplicity, but I am done done done with it because it does not have enough "game" for me. Simple doesn't have to equal lucky or lacking control/decisions. I will totally play this for a laugh, but will shake my head in frustration. While doing so.

My original rating for this game was a 4, but I've since moved it up. I can see the appeal, and it's really just a harmless little filler.  I think the more I play it, I might be kinder towards it, much like my feelings for Citadel (which I, at one point, hated with the heat of a thousand burning stars).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Light fun, but got real old for me real fast. It's a filler, yes, but... even for a filler it feels like it goes by too quickly, or that the decisions you make are too inconsequential. More importantly, it has a very narrow effective player range, and this game just doesn't see the table enough for a filler.

Update: Sold it, since I'll always reach for something else.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b][i]Love Letter[/i][/b] should not be this fun. It's only 16 cards. A long game is 15 minutes. It feels sort of like you're playing paper-rock-scissors. These are the qualities of a bad game, right? And yet, unlike paper-rock-scissors, you have just enough information to have a guess about what your opponents might be planning. Sure, you're not playing a complicated game, and sure, some games you'll throw rock when you should have thrown scissors even though there was no way you could have known; c'est la vie. But other times you'll double-bluff your opponent to a rousing victory. All of this in 16 cards and 15 minutes? It might be the most fun per cubic meter second in existence.

◊s◊

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is 3 player gold right here. This is everything you could expect a $10 game with 16 cards to be. It's truly a gem. It plays super fast once everyone is on board, there's constant action. There is a chance you can get eliminated, but you're only out for the round which is 2 minutes tops, and it is just as interesting to watch it play out. REALLY shines with 3, with 4 it's still good/playable. Gets especially bluff-y when playing with more seasoned players. Always begs for another game once you get started. I have no hesitation giving this a perfect 10, and that's something I don't do lightly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excelleny quick play, rules lite (there are only 16 cards) card game. Cards represent characters at the Palace - each charcter has and ability and a rank. Each player has just one card representing their character. Each turn a player draws one card and then must play one of his 2 cards and complete the ability of that played card in an effort to eliminate the other players , or finish the round with the highest ranked card in hand. 

Simple, great components and good fun for all.

RATING: 10
Easily the best filler I own. Newbies and experienced gamers seem to like this one. It's really all about counting, but the unused card per round makes that an inexact science. There's just enough mystery and guessing to make this one surprising and replayable. Yawn at people calling Euros elegant. This is an elegant little card game. While poor bluffers can unintentionally divulge info, I can't think of any flaws in this game itself. I wouldn't change a thing.

RATING: 3
4 bucks from work, I couldn't argue.
Now I know why there's such odd licensed versions of this - any theme could be used here.

It's a simple game and quick, which is good for my kids.

A solid 'Meh.' Good for learning greater-than and less-than for kids. My kids quickly grew tired of this and so it was handed off to some one younger.

Again, another one of those games that I just don't understand the hype around. It's a bunch of cards, draw one, play it. Highest wins the round. Repeat.
I'm not sure why this has such a high rating.

情書，猜來猜去的角色遊戲，很快上手，適合各種年齡層玩。
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The most popular re-themed game of 2013. 
A brilliant study in simplicity. The game contains only 16 cards.  Each card depicts a person in the royal court, some of whom may have more influence with the princess and might be willing to slip her your particular letter of chaste flirtation, which she will read tonight by the fire. 
You want it to be your letter, right? Not the player to your left or right, or that smug bastard sitting across from you. None of them deserve her hand, and if you have to use your connections to see to it that their letter ends up IN the fire, then so be it. All's fair in love and war.

It takes a few plays to realize there is one basic strategy to this game, but before you get there, you will marvel at how well this works, and how fun it can be. It's a great way to introduce new players to a new generation of card games, and it never fails to please. Plus, it's usually priced below ten bucks, so it's an easy purchase.
If I have a critisism, then it's about that one basic strategy. Once you unlock that little gem, the game loses some of it's bite. But I won't reveal that here. 
Also, strictly from a design standpoint, the game almost looks like it should be sitting on your daughter's dressing table next to her Bella Sara cards and pink sunglasses. 
Don't be put off by it's "girly" texture.
I re-themed this game with crassly animated Venture Brothers and Pirate motifs and they fit perfectly.
There you go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is quite frankly one of the best designed games to ever hit my table. I tend to hate the overuse of the word "elegant" in terms of game design, but this one truly is elegant. It strikes just the right balance between luck and strategy, even employing some level of meta-strategy. (It's not just what cards you play but how you, as the player, play them and react to them.) 16 cards can, and do, make for hours of enjoyment.

RATING: 9
The proverbial big game in a small box! A superb filler. For less than £8, every gamer should own this. It plays well with 2-4 people, and, while luck dependent, has a good deal of bluff, second-guessing and tactics. Topped off with very nice presentation, and a refreshingly original theme (even if it's odd, not to say disturbing, that the townspeople's response to the Princess' mother being arrested for High Treason is to try to make her feel better by sending her love letters).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The proverbial big game in a small box! A superb filler. For less than £8, every gamer should own this. It plays well with 2-4 people, and, while luck dependent, has a good deal of bluff, second-guessing and tactics. Topped off with very nice presentation, and a refreshingly original theme (even if it's odd, not to say disturbing, that the townspeople's response to the Princess' mother being arrested for High Treason, is to try to make her feel better by sending her love letters).

The Japanese artwork is a lot better than the "western" version, in my opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The theme is:

- sexist
- boring
- completely unintegrated with gameplay.

Yuck!

A minimalist deduction game could be fun, but this is surprisingly inelegant for its size. Some draws can doom you through no fault of your own; the first few plays of each hand are random; the varying card counts are clunky.

I'm sure some of my comments are novice misconceptions, but life's too short to play games that are neither fun nor intriguing the first time around.

Oh, right, and it relies on people not accidentally cheating when they draw the Countess.

Also, the "first to 4" scoring means that game length can vary wildly, and is usually longer than the person who's super-excited about playing remembers. [Update: I was told the Japanese edition is just one short round, and it was AEG who declared that you had to play until someone wins four times. I suspect I'd like this a lot more if I'd been introduced to it as a game you play for 4 minutes. Probably still wouldn't love it.]

RATING: 9
"Love Letter" is simply one of the most brilliant pieces of game design I've seen for the last few years.  16 cards, no more, no less.  A rule set which fits on less than half a sheet of paper.  And tons of fun.  Technically its just a simple game of guessing, bluffing and deduction.  I've played it with a number of various groups during the last weeks and it was an instant hit in each of these groups.  I hope that this game will hit the German market soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This cute little pocket-sized game is just too precious not to own.  It's a very light deduction game that is easy and quick to play, but still presents players with a enough meaningful choices to make the game interesting.  Did I mention that this game was cute?  

It's not brilliant, but games like these are good to have in a collection.  It can be nice way to start a game night, or something to bring out when you are entertaining non-gamers.  It's good on road trips or as a way to kill time between events at cons.  Furthermore, players who get squeamish around fantasy swords or sci-fi blasters will not find this off-putting.

I recommend you try this one the next time you and your Mother have tea.  The two of you will have such a lovely time.

The only reason I am giving it a 3 rather than a 2 is because if someone else really wanted to play it I would probably oblige even while knowing I had no hope of winning any round except for due to an incredible stroke of luck.

RATING: 8
D.A

y mine en P&P :D

Parece sencillo, y lo es... pero al mismo tiempo tiene su miga, y da para bastante debate en el grupo de jugadores. :D

La premisa es sencilla... conseguir conservar la carta de valor mas alto en la mano, y si es la princesa mucho mejor. Conseguirlo ya es otra historia. 

Muy rejugable y un excelente filler. 

El mayor defecto? la sinopsis. te empiezan a hablar de cartas de amor a la princesa y te piensas que el juego es un pasteleo. nada mas lejos de la realidad. Es un juego de roles, con algo de blufeo y sobre todo con mucha doble y hasta triple intencion. muy recomendable para toda clase de publico. 

hay una version P&P de Star Wars que esta muy bien. la mayoria de P&Ps son bastante flojos (a pesar de que el juego se presta para ello) pero ese en concreto y alguno que otro mas, merecen el trabajo de imprimir y cortar.

RATING: 9
Just genius. Takes the interesting role-guessing and deduction bit from Citadels, and lets you play that for 20 minutes without all the other junk. Making each turn a binary choice is the key success of this game I think - your options are limitted so you can't get stuck in deduction paralysis, but you have to factor in available information and player behaviour to your decision so often there isn't just a clear best choice. It really is good.

RATING: 8
