=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Letter is a quick and simple role selection game that is really all about bluffing with a dash of deduction. The comparisons to Citadels are really inevitable. 

The component quality is not good, as the cards tend to show wear far too easily. In a game that relies on hidden information, this is a Bad Thing. Additionally, it comes in a drawstring bag, rather than a box. This would be annoying for any game in terms of putting it on your shelf, but it is an especially stupid way to store cards. 

In many ways, as mentioned, this game plays like a stripped-down version of Citadels. No money to deal with, no buildings or bonuses to keep track of. It simply awards you points for guessing your opponents' choices correctly. This is honestly a good improvement as Citadels can drag with more players. Unfortunately, Love Letter only supports 2-4 players, which are the same player counts when Citadels it at its best. 

Ultimately, I think it's a toss-up as to which one is better. I like the ability to support higher player counts that Citadels has, but the stripped-down simplicity of Love Letter is also appealing. There is room in a collection for both, but owning one already may significantly de-prioritize picking up the other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
ESSEN 2012

RATING: 6

Totally replaced by Lost Legacy for me, which does everything this game does and has the same central draw-one-play-one mechanic, but has much more interesting cards and a more strategy-allowing win condition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is an engaging little card game, with a good deal of luck, and some bluffing in a very social small deck game.

It seems to play well with new gamers and old, and is a fun, fairly quick filler from Seiji Kanai, designer of Chronicle.

Like Chronicle, every card played has special powers, but since the deck is even shorter the luck factor is greater, and the hand play is very quick and to the point.

I found it a winner, but if players are at all slow in play in can outstay it's welcome fairly easily - there is not a ton of strategy here so much as a lot of fun playing the game.

Starting this at a 7, after a couple of 4-player games.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players are suitors full of eager genetic material trying to use various flunkies and dissolute aristocrats to deliver a note to Her Royal Uterus.  The winner of each round earns a "token of affection", a little red cube that most assuredly does not represent chlamydia or herpes.

UPDATE:  This game is about 9,000 times more fun than it has any right to be—16 cards and some cubes?  Passing notes to a princess?  [i]Really?[/i]  But the end result is a quick, light farce that really does feel like scurrying through gardens and halls, of tarrying in chambers at improper hours, all on the little cat feet of whispers and meaningful glances.

The genius of the game comes from the small set of interactions possible with the cards, making the deduction element satisfying enough for the time frame involved (read:  short & sweet).  Were it any more vexing or longer it would be a failure—but [i]Love Letter[/i] is a bonbon of precise proportions, mild and delicious.

(Up-rezzed with [thing=141584]Heart Tokens[/thing].)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I will not always want to play Love Letter, but I think it is a perfect game, and thus deserving of a 10. I see a lot of people write this off as very shallow with "automatic decisions," and others have chimed in, correctly, that the game is all about the metagame. My stance on metagame as a central mechanic (which is arguable, but I think it's clear that Love Letter was designed with this intent and that the metagame is absolutely necessary to bringing it from a luck-based card game to something slightly deeper) is up in the air, but I'm a fan of it here. If you're not holding the Princess you will almost never have an easy decision. Double Handmaid and the mandatory Countess plays are the only exceptions, assuming there's more than 2 people left in the round. The easiest counter-example is Baron-Guard but within a stable metagame even that decision becomes trickier. 

The first "Aha!" moment in Love Letter will likely involve the Countess. This is not difficult to notice, especially for seasoned gamers, but it is certainly counter-intuitive on the very first play of the game. When first playing Love Letter people will often hold on to the Countess, knowing it's a high card and likely to get them a victory. Eventually, when you are forced to play it and you get triple-Guarded, knocking you out of the game, you will realize that you can play the Countess automatically no matter what you have, and after enough time other players will realize they are wasting their time with repeated Guard guesses. Doing this repeatedly makes you safer when you do inevitably hold Countess-Prince/King/Princess. And in the end this is what Love Letter is about - making plays that make those "automatic decision" moments harder to read for your opponents. This is where the beauty of the game starts to shine. 

I often get badgered into playing this with 3, but if I had my way I'd never play with less than 4. Perfect amount of chaos, deduction, and control.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Super light game that consists of 16 cards. They are numbered 1-8, some more than others. The goal is to not be eliminated and to have the highest numbered card when the draw pile is gone.

It is very simple to teach--you only hold one card, you draw a card, and you must discard/activate one card. It is also very portable. There isn't much to the game, but casual gamers seem to love it.

I've played with 5 people at work during lunch hour--they don't seem to mind that means less turns per hand. It is functional.

RATING: 6

It's a rarity in gaming land though in being plain and simple knockabout fun. Admittedly the theme is weak and doesn't relate to the play, but if you accept this for what it is then it's a great piece of gaming minimalism.

RATING: 9.5
Probably the best filler game for 2-4 players ever conceived.  It's quick, portable, has a nice mix of luck and tactics (including bluffing), and plays equally well for 2-4 players.  You can take it camping, play it on an airplane, play it at work... anywhere, really.  Be sure to sleeve your copy, though, because a marked card would ruin the game.  Not to mention, you'll probably wear out the cards with how often you'll find yourself playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably like this more than I should but it just fits one of the groups of people I play games with so god dang perfectly. It facilitates just the right kind of table talk, has the amount of luck necessary to cushion any ego and enough skill involved to keep it interesting while not being to straining.

I wouldn't usually pick this up as a main game on a game night but then on the other hand it has often gone from being the planned warm-up game to swallowing the better part of the evening.

Then again I don't think it's a game to be overthought. You just kinda have to wan't to win more than you know that you reasonably should and to wan't your friends to lose more than chance deem that they should to have Love Letter shine.

If you have a hard time of letting go of the more reasonable way of approaching a game I'm not sure Love Letter will necessarily appeal to you. At least for me I had to switch that part of me off to have as great of a time as I've had with Love Letter.

RATING: 5
It's random. It's short. It's ok.

It's not really my sort of game, but it does fill the role of "filler" to a T. My main problem with the game was how it initially seemed to be billed as a "deduction" game, and thus I was disappointed at how little deductive strategies played a part in the game's progression. But once I threw out those preconceptions, I was able to enjoy it for what it is. I would definitely not play it with less than three though, as the two-player version is influenced far too much by chance for my liking. I'm not sure I understand why it continues to rate so highly in certain circles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love Letter is a fun and extremely easy to learn card game with just a little bit of thinking and deduction, making it ideal as a gateway, a filler, or something to play with the family.

The game is comprised of 20 cards, 13 cubes aaaand... that's it! Its really quite genius, because its not just impressively small, but its so novel and inventive that they managed to pack so much game into so few components.

The game itself is very simple to learn - you hold a card in your hand representing one of eight characters who can help you get your letter to the princess. On your turn you draw a second card and then decide which of the two you're going to play. The card you play may help you eliminate your opponents, but the player holding the highest ranking card at the end wins the round.

For something so simple, there's really a lot of entertainment value there. The game is quite interactive, and the various card combinations can lead to silly scenarios and some great laughs. There are a few tactical decisions, which keep you engaged, but for the most part you just go with the flow and relax.

This game works for so many situations, its really a must buy. Travel? Yes... Filler? Yes... Kids? Yes... Grandma? Yes... Boys night? Not so much... Starting a game collection and don't have much money? Yes... Having another couple over for dinner? Very YES!

All that and it costs next to nothing - you really should get this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Perfekt för hela familjen, när man vill ta det lite lugnt och ska spela med icke inbitna spelare.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Quick and easy game where up to 4 players try to win the heart of the princess by giving their love letters to different characters that have different levels of closeness to the princess. The players that ends the game with the closest character (represented by the highest number, from 1 of the guardians to the 8 of the princess) wins. The game is so fast that the idea is playing several rounds with the winner being the first to win 5 or 6 rounds.
Positive:
1. Easy to explain
2. Easy to play
3. So fast that you do not have time to get bored
4. A great game for trips
Negative:
1. There is not a lot of strategy, the combination of cards makes the rounds repetitive

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game was just really FUN, and close to the perfect filler (depending on what you are looking for, of course...). It reminded me a a little of a boiled down version of Citadels with the 8 roles and how they interact.  

NO rules to learn or teach, very fast and fluid. Minimal decisions and very high on luck however so be warned. Also, our game ran at least 20 minutes since it was very close at the end not like the 5 or 10min reports I read (and we played with 4). Basically what you have is a little bluff and lots of guessing, some educated.  

We played with the new version of the rules, and in reading the old ones, I think the new version is better since it introduces more bluffing and reduces the luck of the draw a little as well.  

Best with [-]four for sure[/-] [b]five or six[/b], I could see 3 good/okay but 2 a completely different experience. Probably not something you want to overplay or might feel too samey too quick, otherwise a great occasional filler.  Talk about a great gateway game too, hook your non-gaming co-workers at lunch-time...My rating could rise slightly if it remains that fun the next 4 games.

Tidbit - If you want it a touch shorter, play to 3 points

Tidbit2 - Sleeve everything and scan a few of the original cards and add them into the mix to play up to 6 players. It will dilute the balance a little with respect to the Princess and higher cards, and be a little tougher to win but I sometimes find myself in a group of 6 non-gamers and this will be a great option I don't want to pass up and expect it to work pretty good overall. 


[u]UPDATE:[/u]  Played my Game of Thrones 6 player version today and it was a lot of fun, it worked very well and everyone enjoyed it, I think AEG missed an opportunity here for sure, the game would likely play okay with 7 or 8 (but not as good as 5/6). I think the game might be best with 5 now as just a suspicion, but there were no real issues with 6. Note I did tweak a couple of the rules/cards [See Baelish in image Gallery for one example] for theme and balance and added one extra role for good measure, and I am also using a hybrid of both AEG and Japon rules for some cards (and it works well since Japon is too harsh, and AEG is too lenient [7 card] especially for a bigger group). 

An additional rule needed when playing with 6 is "you can't be targeted by the "number 1" more than 3 times in one round", and of course play to only 2 points (I think 3 points [not 4] is better for 4 also). With 5 or 6 players and the Game of Thrones theme I'd rate it 8.5, the Theme fits SOOOO well too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a nice quick game.  You can play a round in maybe ten minutes.  There is a set of cards running from low soldiers to the high princess.  You all have a hand size of one.  Each turn you draw a card, keep one and play one.  The one you play has different effects like you might eliminate a player if you guess the card in their hand.  The highest card amongst the surviving players when the deck runs out is the winner.  So light but meaningful deductions and reading tells.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Love Letter doesn't have much depth, but it doesn't need to have that. It's a short game that can be taught quickly. It has a heavy element of luck, but smart plays to present themselves from time to time to keep things somewhat interesting.

As long as players take their turns quickly, it's a pleasant filler game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Lots of fun. It's a tactical card game, yet it's more lively fun than some of the party games we have.

As a 2-player game it's just ok. As a 4-player game it's extraordinary.

My game group prefers this game to all other games that we normally play. (like Pandemic, Elder Sign, Innovation)

Forget the premise about a love letter. When you play the game you're not thinking about that at all. You're just thinking about how to stay in the game while you're trying to eliminate everyone else.

For a game that consists of a mere 16 cards, it packs a huge amount of strategy, luck, skill, confrontation, psychology, twists, and surprise endings. This is a truly incredible game.

[Edit: after 6 plays, increasing to a 9]

[Edit: after 30 plays I'm really getting tired of it, but each time I play I do have fun; keeping it at a 9 for now -- the game deserves it]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really fun, really light game.  There's only 16 cards in the deck with a variety of values and powers.  You want to end each round with the highest value card, but having a high-value card makes it more likely you'll be eliminated from the round.  The winner is the first player to win a certain number of rounds, based on the number of players.  Update: One thing I've noticed after a few plays is that the game is not as short as it seems like it would be.  Each round is usually pretty quick, but the game often seems to go 10 or 12 rounds, which can drag it out, especially with slow players.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first time you see this game, you're going to think it looks kinda dumb, possibly cornball. There's a whole story about how the princess is distraught over her mother's betrayal of the kingdom, and the only way to make her feel better is by delivering love letters to her. Through the game play, you're basically figuring out who delivers your letter via points, and if you win, you've won her favor for that day, in the form of a little red block. This game is actually a lot of fun, you're basically trying to have the card with the highest point value at the end of each round. What makes it so entertaining is that while there aren't that many cards, no round is the same. There's some guesswork, some strategy and some mind gaming too. Plus, it's super portable and cheap!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fast, fun (in a sometimes silly way) little filler.

That being said: short, fun game and a welcome addition to my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This comment is for the AEG edition.

2013-02-14

Initial Rating: 7.0 (February 2013)

Quick fun game. Very easy to teach. It has a healthy dose of luck, but it also has a crucial bluffing component (which I like) and it plays so quickly that I don’t mind the luck. It also has player elimination, but you are eliminated for about 2 minutes, so I don’t mind that either. It seems to pack a lot of interesting decisions with only 16 cards!

Perfect filler for 3 or 4 players. Not so sure about 2 players. 

I wanted to buy the game today and I saw that they were selling around US$40, WTF? I guess I will wait for a reprint. 

Current Rating: 7.0
[hr]
2014-08-19

I no longer want to play Love Letter. I (generally) don’t subscribe to the philosophy that a game replaces another, but when I play Love Letter, I found myself wanting to play Coup, so I’m downgrading its rating. It is a good game, but Coup is superior in every way. I’m selling my copy of the game and I will only hang onto the Kanai edition because it was a gift from a friend. 

Current Rating: 6.0
[hr]
2016-02-02

I’m very tired of the proliferation of micro games and Love Letter clones. When I play Love letter I feel like I’m wasting my precious gaming time. Love Letter is way too long for what it offers. I need meatier games. I will do my best to never play it again.

Love Letter is no longer among my favorite games of 2012. 
 
Current Rating: 4.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This comment is for the Kanai Factory Edition.

2014-08-19

Initial Rating: 6.0 (August 2014)

I finally played with this edition. As Love Letter has recently fallen in my personal ratings, I’m rating it at a 6.0. A good game that I can play from time to time, still Love Letter no longer excites me. Coup is superior in every way so I almost always ply Coup instead.

I like the art of this edition, but if I have to choose, I would choose the art from the AEG edition, but I do like more the power of the countess in this edition. When I play, I think I would play this way.

Not much more to say about it, see also my comment for the AEG edition.

Love Letter is no longer among my favorite games of 2012. 

Current Rating: 6.0

RATING: 7.5
Draw a card, play a card — and hope that card you played can force another player into discarding theirs (and thus going out of the game). It's really a question of logic based on lucky draws.

HUGE PLUS: inexpensive, strong production values, portable
PLUS: works well as a starting game, inexpensive

ESSENTIAL if you want a quick starter game you can take anywhere

RATING: 7.5
A lovely (pun semi-intended) filler game with elements of deduction, bluffing and tactical decision making. The game is really simple with the downside being that the game is really random and the players often can't really control the outcome of the game. It's not uncommon for a player to get eliminated from the round before their first turn for example. Some minor annoyances aside, Love Letter is a clever little game that I really enjoy playing.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A delightful deduction filler game that created the micro game genre.  If played well, part of the game is deduction, but even a greater part of the game is psychology.  You must ask yourself, why did my opponent ask me if I had "such and such"?  Is it because that card is a threat to their card, or is it because they have that card and want to deceive me, or is it their best guess?  If you don't pause to consider the psychology of your opponent, you are missing the beauty of this little game.

[b]Star ranking[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Kind of like the board game equivalent of Wolverine, it's the best there is at what it does. You couldn't build a game night around Love Letter, but it so perfectly fills those empty spaces between brain-burners. And its small format makes it ideal for travelling; made even better by the velvet bag (to the point that if it didn't come with one, I would have downed a bottle of Crown Royal just for the bag...)

What's more, it suits pretty well every crowd. Non gamers pick it up easily, and the apprehension of 'serious' gamers might feel at the game with the name 'Love Letter' is easily dismissed once they see how quickly and elegantly it plays.

I can't recommend this game enough. An absolutely perfect filler.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players have one card in their hand and on their turn draw another one to play one of them and execute the effects. The winner is the player that survives and has the most valuable card in hand after the 16 cards are played. Only roll-and-move could be simpler. 
You can't get much more play value out of 3 EUR and 16 cards. Love Letter surprisingly manages to pull off a fun 15 minute game with a topic that's almost embarrasing for a true geek. Nice to see such a game when new games are routinely priced with 40-50 EUR at their release in Essen.

RATING: 4
Rating for Tempest-themed version. 

Best micro-game to date. And I curse it for causing that trend. Still, great, simple deduction game.

I *hate* the Kanai Factory version though. The art is hideous, and the slightly different roles are subtle but really taint the gameplay. Countess > Minister. The Countess' ability removes the element of losing entirely by luck with the Minister (Which is how most people with the Minster lose).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great little game that is easily learned and has been a universal hit with everyone I've taught. I enjoy the simplicity of the decisions and the bluffing opportunity. It's too bad that AEG decided to put their own branding on top. The artwork is clearly inferior unless you care about the "tempest universe". I also prefer the original rules - playing to five cubes makes the game way too long. The way AEG treated this game reminds me of the way Mayfair treated all the early games like Settlers, E&T and Modern Art. It makes no sense at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is how the game should have been released. AEG is just as bad as Mayfair, if not worse. Why replace artwork with something that is uglier and more annoying due to its branding. At least Mayfair just ruined artwork rather than trying to sell me on the "Tempest universe". It makes me mad that I gave AEG my money twice.

RATING: 7.5
Love Letter is one of the most elegant pieces of game design I've ever played, and anyone can pick up the rules in under a minute. It is a perfect warm-up game or introductory game that can lead to interest in other card-driven games later on, with Coup feeling like the most obvious next step.

What's more than that, it's just plain fun, especially in a group of four.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A rather clever little game, where the word "little" would apply even without the disparaging connotations it doesn't entirely escape. In the end I don't think there's much game here, but more of an activity with many forced, obvious or arbitrary choices where the payoff is more revelation than calculation ("Oh, so you [i]had[/i] the Princess!"). There are obvious reasons why Love Letter does well in the BGG ranking, but as a GeekBuddy noted, being short is not enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I play with two decks and with 4 custom roles:

1: Assassin - kill a Guard if they guess you

RATING: 9
For a filler, this is more fun than it should be. The cards have interlocking powers that sometimes allow you to kill another player due to no fault of his/her own, but you can also enact enormous screwups and since you play until someone hits four letters, I think it's fair enough. I really like the art and theme - as one of the people I was playing with a BGG.con said, when you can get three straight guys at a table playing a game named "Love Letter," you have, in a sense, already won.

Three cheers for Japon Brand. Given the varied and engaging play of LL and Chronicle, I really hope they keep sending the odd card game over to American companies. I'm sure their games aren't uniformly excellent, but man, those two sure are.

RATING: 8
Traded: Love Letter: Kanai Factory Limited Edition
Publisher/Edition: AEG Third Edition 2013
Language: English
Condition: Excellent. Cards are sleeved and included. The insert was cut in half to fit the sleeved cards and the instruction book is folded in half.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a really solid game that revels in its own simplicity. I like describing it as "the game where your hand is always one card" which, while not literally true, does capture the essence, and intrigues a lot of people. 

The fact that it's quick, straightforward, and tiny makes it a situationally good game, but also something that doesn't find its way to the table all that often - it's actually so low in complexity that it often doesn't seem worth teaching to new people, especially now that we've built up a collection of deeper games that are almost as beginner-friendly. 

However, that doesn't overrule the fact that, as a game, it's really fun, and nearly perfect in design (we learned and continue to use one house rule concerning the Minister, but otherwise play it exactly as written). I like that it can vary a bit in length just by changing the threshold for winning pips, and it's a really good time filler/brain break when doing a longer session. It is also strong for a wide variety of player numbers; I think it's actually listed for 2-4, but it works okay as a 5-player game, too, and probably 6 although it would get rather short at that point. 

The theme is a bit hit-or-miss. I personally like it a lot, even if it's a little cheesy, but it's sooo peripheral to the game that sometimes it puts people off. I almost wish there was a version that simply had the card numbers without any theming at all (actually, one could adapt a couple standard decks for it, but you'd have to memorize all the abilities), as some people seem a bit reticent to play a game with this theme. On the other hand, some people are really drawn to it, so it's kind of 50/50. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For what it is this is a good little game. It is a great game for anyone new to the hobby and all players generally enjoy playing and pick the game up quickly. Personally I will not pick the game if there are other options to play but am happy to play if asked. Recommended, a good game for what it is.

:star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (20 plays August 2016)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Given to my daughter, who really enjoys it. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This comment is after just one play, but I think Love Letter has a lot more going for it than you would expect, considering that it's just 16 cards and some cubes in a cloth bag. While it would obviously be categorized as a filler, I think you could play the game several times in a row and not get the least bit tired of it.

As an interactive game, LL is obviously at its best with more players (we played with three, though, and still had a great time). But it's important to remember that the crucial choices in the game are not so much what card you play, but instead, which other player you play it on. But there's even more to it than that. I love the misdirection and bluffing aspects of the game, as well as the deduction. And it all comes together in a tiny, affordable little package.

The design of the cards is excellent, though I would have liked some sort of tuckbox for the cards. The game could easily get damaged in a backpack or pocket, and the velvet bag isn't going to offer much protection.

Most of all, Love Letter is a lot of fun! We thoroughly enjoyed it, and can't wait to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of my favorite games. There is a opinion that this game does not work with two players, but i play this with my wife all the time and works perfectly. Strategically you have to play it a bit differently, as it is unlikely that you will win by method of high card, but still an excellent game for two people. We also play by a minor house rule change of starting the game by playing "two" cards face down and "two" cards face up, improved the two player version a lot for us. Great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Love Letter is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. Your goal is to get your love letter into Princess Annette's hands while deflecting the letters from competing suitors. From a deck with only sixteen cards, each player starts with only one card in hand; one card is removed from play. On a turn, you draw one card, and play one card, trying to expose others and knock them from the game. Powerful cards lead to early gains, but make you a target. Rely on weaker cards for too long, however, and your letter may be tossed in the fire!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the best short card game going around.

It is also a brilliant example of how much a theme and artwork can add to a game. What is more memorable: When you look down at your cards and see two threes? Or look down at your cards and see two barons?

Many other cards games held up on BGG provide a game experience similar to conventional card games, or that can easily be recreated with conventional games. Love Letter doesn't, and is enjoyed by nearly all I've played it with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
I don't get it. Ok, it's fast. 
Here is another game even faster : roll a dice, and whoever has the highest number wins...

I had this kind of feeling. My two first games, I was out of the game before it was even my turn. Didn't do anything. At all. 

Too much luck, too fast, even for a filler. 
Should maybe give it another try.

Update:
Tried again with 2 players. Way too luck dependent. Rating unchanged.
On a side note, I was mentioning the idea of an even more stupid game by rolling dice. I am now the proud owner of "Angry dice", which basically is the exact thing I described. Can't stop progress.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I finally get to see what the fuss has all been about. The design is completely brilliant. Packing so much of a game in so few components is nothing short of revolutionary game design. My hats are off to Mr. Kanai for that. That being said there isnt all that much of a game in this tiny box. So its more like a curse and a blessing all at the same time. The game plays smoothly and well, and there are definitely interesting choices to make throughout. Ultimately though it just feels like you are almost picking stones out of a bag blindly, and whoever picks the white stone wins! With microgrames I just think I need a little bit more meat to the game to really hold my interest. I wouldn't mind playing this, especially considering its short playing time, but I don't need to own it.

RATING: 6.5
PNP version (Japan/AEG version not yet available in HK) 
This game is a buzz in Essen 12 and was sold out in 1-2 hrs?  

For me i defintely like the Japanese version better due to its unique graphics.  

The game play is quick with a dose of luck, memeory and some hand management.  A nice filler but can get boring/repetitive if we want to deliver all 4 letters.  Also the leader can eaily be picked on in a 4 player game, with ppl guessing him/her with soldier each turn.  

overall i think it is a good game for what it offers but the $12 US price tag is a bit bit ambious.

I think i will stick with my PNP version unless i found the original Jap version

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was another surprising drop for me. Don't get me wrong, I'm still always down to woo the Princess, but it's reached the point that Love Letter is only good with certain groups of people, and I've just accepted the fact that many people don't "get" it. There's so much depth in Love Letter than many realize, and it's definitely a game where you play the other players as much as the game itself. I prefer it two player (and the occasional house rule), but it's still solid with up to 4. Any more than that is too many though, and the number of meaningful decisions you can make drops way down.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love letter is a light game of deduction with a splash of screw your buddy. Some times it's simply hoping you make it past a somewhat random early game to get to the heart of the play where the real decisions take place. More often than not, there are smart decisions to be made for the entirety of play and you will often look back and see what you could have done "right" for the next play. Any game you can learn from tells me that the game space has room for you to grow as a player and make intelligent decisions.

Sometimes you'll get screwed, but most of the time there's tension and fun. Given the short duration and round structure, the fun is all you'll remember.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Type: 

Best with: 2-4
Weight: Light
Duration: 10-25 minutes
Notes:

Love Letter is an extremely portable, light head-to-head card game.

There actually isn't much to say about this game, as reading my comments could take longer than it takes to teach the game or play a couple rounds. 

On the upside, this game is insanely portable, easy to teach, and does offer a decent amount of replayability for 2 up to 5 players, and works just as well with all of those numbers.

On the downside, there is a lot of luck involved, but that's what makes it fun and light, too.

Similar games in my collection: oddball Aeronauts (light, portable, card-based direct competitive 1-on-1), Court of the Medici (light, card-based, direct competition game for 2 players).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A small, simple card game that packs a good bit of game in a small package.  There are many versions of this but all are basically the same.  There are nine card types each with a unique function.  You play until you are the only player remaining or have the highest value card.  This earns you one point.  You continue to play hands until you achieve a certain number of points based on number of players.  

This is a great family game.  Easy to learn and play.  The rules around the Countess can be forgotten, but that is the only tricky rule for a new player.  

I like this game a lot and highly recommend it.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The ultimate filler game.   You can squeeze 15 plays of this into a little under half an hour as long as everyone knows how to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
this is a great little game. It's essentially a deduction game but you also have some chances to take out our rivals. Mistakes or dumb moves provide hilarity - usually with the perpetrator having no idea what they just did. 

Examples: 

player with king & princess decides wants to play the king and discard his own hand, discards princess and kills himself! 

Player with prince and guard plays prince and swaps hands with player on left giving them their guard. Person on the left now knows what the person on their right has because they just passed it to them and have just been gifted a guard. Plays guard. Eliminates person to right!  Person to the right realises mistake - doh!

New player shows everyone their cards when priest is played! 

Etc.

Played with 2 3 and 4 and all are good but 3/4 is best.

Rating changed from 7->9 based on more plays

RATING: N/A
Very tight little game, with very minimal components, and just a fun little game.  Takes about 5 minutes to play, 2 minutes to teach, and has just enough logic and deduction to make it interesting.  Cody loves it, I'm not super into it, so I won't bother getting it, but I wouldn't turn down playing it, just wouldn't do so a bunch of times in a short time period.

Bought a copy for Aunt Kim's family for '14 Christmas, since it's great interaction and really only good for 3-4 players anyway.  Bought myself a copy as well.  Both copies are the Legend of the Five Rings versions, though, in my case because I want to be different, for Aunt Kim's family so Ian maybe is a bit more interested since it's samurai and a green bag.  Also a buck less.  Didn't get for Uncle Ron's family since they would often have more than 4 anyway.

RATING: 7.5
A lovely little game that first not really caught my attention when we tried it as a filler in the regular game group. It was to light for that purpose.
But when the kids found it and asked what it was about it became an absolute hit.
They have been playing it constantly for four month now and it is so inpiering to see them develop new strategies to deduce me, their friends and each other in the strive of the princess affection. 
It is a sincerely light and quick game. Very little strategi but loaded with tactics and a certain amount of luck. Though it is deep enough to serve as a gateway game to card games and so entertaining because all kids above 6 year can play it with equall chance of victory as hard core eurogamers.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
A couple got this for me and my wife over the holidays. We all heard how great it is and were eager to give it a shot. Right off the bat my wife got the hang of the game and got 3 cubes. We were sure she was going to win so we all ganged up on her. After that she only had one turn to play anything. She was effectively locked out of the game.

I caught up quickly to her and then people started ganging up on me. The last round saw all of us with 3 cubes and it all came down to who got lucky. My wife and I were out first and second.

The game can take way too long to play, especially if someone has analysis paralysis. There is definitely a lot of player interaction unless you get ahead. Then everyone gangs up on you and you're lucky to get to play a turn. My wife, after quickly getting 3 cubes, took one turn in 6 rounds of play.

I find Coup a much better, similar, game. There is player elimination but a game won't last long. We could have played 3 games of Coup in the time it took to play one game of Love Letter. I hope I never play this terrible game again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

5,00

its just such a guessing game.  there are times where there is some deduction/bluff but was just enough for me to want more of that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lightning-fast rounds keep this friendly and amusing, even when cutthroat tactics are used.  Anyone can play this and have a good time, and the fact that it's so portable (and attractively packaged!) means that it sees a ton of play.  Very luck-reliant, which suits my mood more on some days than others.

Also, I think it's best with 3-4 rather than 2 players.  That way, one player's run of ridiculous luck can be distributed somewhat evenly, instead of one person getting pathetically shut out for a long streak.

Only a 7 because of the 2-player flaw and because decisions really aren't that challenging.

RATING: 5
7.0 - Jul 2014 - 8 Plays:  This one barely squeaks into a 7, by virtue of it short duration and portability.  It's easy enough to teach just about anyone, and there is just enough meat present to make it fun.  If I'm traveling it will almost always come with us, but at home there are many games that I would rather play.

6.0 - Jan 2015 - 9 Plays:  While I had said it barely squeaks into a 7, it's only been played once in the last 6 months.  It can still be fun, but it can also be completely infuriating.  I'm hoping to try Lost Legacy soon, which may cause Love Letter to take another ratings dive.

5.0 - Sept 2015 - 10 Plays:  My prediction came true.  We picked up a couple versions of Lost Legacy and I would never choose to play Love Letter over Lost Legacy.

RATING: 5.5
Put me in the meh camp on this one.  There are two levels to this game.  You can play it as a simple guessing game for which it is not that good.  Or you can try to delve deeper into the deduction side of things which makes it more interesting, but since it is such a short game, the pay off for the amount of brain power/memory you need just doesn't add up.

I would play this again because it is quick and inoffensive, but not because I searched it out.

RATING: 6
While I understand some people disliking this game because it feels random, I enjoy for it what it is: A simple to teach card game that you can carry in your bag.  Because of how quickly each round is, the randomness effect is irrelevant.  It’s easy to teach to both gamers and non-gamers with a small footprint on the table.  

If you are looking for a “gamier” version of Love Letter, I highly recommend Lost Legacy.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
LL does exactly what it says on the tin: Packs a good amount of light strategy and tactics into a very tiny, fast-playing package. I'm surprised at the amount of depth it squeezes into and out of just 16 cards, and that depth is just right for a game that takes 10-15 minutes.

Even getting knocked out after my first turn twice, I still had fun. Unlike most games with player elimination (even forgiving, "one round only" elimination, as in LL), it's fun to watch and it doesn't take long until you're back in the hunt.

---

After a second play, I bumped it to an 8. There's a delightful light quality to it that I really appreciate: No individual hand matters much, so I don't take it too seriously -- but they matter in aggregate, so I take it just seriously enough. Fun game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Rating based on 3 and 4 players.

For a light, quick card filler I'm not sure how you can get much better than Love Letter, and everyone I've played this with has enjoyed it. There is a good amount of luck, but since rounds play so quickly it doesn't really matter--almost as soon as you're out, the next round begins. 

There are lots of rethemes of this game, but for the super light gameplay I think the fluffy original theme is the best one!

-------------------------------------------------

Gave away to some friends, I'll probably be picking up the Premium Edition later!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love Letter is a very small, and quick, card game for 2-4 people.  The game is played over a varying number of rounds dependent upon the number of players.  To start, one card is secretly set aside.  Then everyone else gets one card.  From there players take turns drawing a card, then playing one of the two cards in their hand.  Each card has a special ability, and numerical value.  To win a round you have to either be the last one not eliminated, or have the highest numbered card by the end.

Love Letter packs a lot of strategy and variety into a very small game.  This makes it endlessly replayable, also highly portable.  It's an incredible design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Love Letter is a very small, and quick, card game for 2-4 people.  The game is played over a varying number of rounds dependent upon the number of players.  To start, one card is secretly set aside.  Then everyone else gets one card.  From there players take turns drawing a card, then playing one of the two cards in their hand.  Each card has a special ability, and numerical value.  To win a round you have to either be the last one not eliminated, or have the highest numbered card by the end.

Love Letter packs a lot of strategy and variety into a very small game.  This makes it endlessly replayable, also highly portable.  It's an incredible design.  The reason I give this version a 6/10 is because I really dislike the Minister card, which immediately eliminates you if your hand total exceeds 12 points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Helt nyt og uåbnet.

RATING: 5
Cool little game that started the microgaming trend. But it's not that funny trend in my opinion - the problem is that I liked the first 2 games, next 2 were ok but by 5th game I was pretty tired already. 5 games is decent mileage from such a small, cheap game, but it's definitely not the classic people are making it out to be. I want games that are fun more than 5 games even if they're small cardgames - look at 6nimmt for example! I guess I'll take this out every now and then with people who are new to gaming and might like it, but other than that it'll stay in the closet. After 2 years of not playing, we had 20 minutes to kill in queue and happened to have paper and pen, I made my own copy on the fly, it was nice spontaneous boardgaming experience.

2-Player Comment:
* Love Letter works with 2, but 3-4 is preferred.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Detailed review:  http://manualgamer.com/love-letter-review/

In Love Letter, players are suitors seeking to win the attentions of a beautiful princess. So begins a game of deduction and bluff as players try to get their letter into the hands of the princess through various agents at the palace and to foil their opponents’ plans.

Love Letter is a really fun game that plays quickly with minimum downtime between turns.  It involves a mixture of deduction, bluffing, and luck – with plenty of excitement along the way.  Sometimes the cards will conspire against players, but such is the life of those trying to woo a princess.

The game plays differently with two players than with 3 or 4, and the combinations that work great in a two player game can be troublesome when there are more players in the mix.

While there aren’t many components in this game, there is a ton of replayability.  The rules are simple to learn but there are additional layers to the game that reveal themselves over a number of plays.  This game is excellent value given how inexpensive it is.

RATING: 8
For quite a while, this was my favorite filler. It's fun and it's quick. Sure, it's swingy, depends on luck a lot and really allows very limited decision-making, but it's wonderful for when you just want to play something fast, without needing to overthink anything. Plus there are always epic games in which the first player plays a guard and guesses right, then the following player does the same and wins the round just like that.

RATING: 2
01/06/15 Played a four-player game that lasted 54 minutes over 11 rounds. (The box says 20 minutes.) Of that 54 minutes I sat doing nothing about 45 minutes, as I drew the Princess 8 of the 11 rounds and was always immediately knocked out. Twiddling my thumbs for 45 of 54 minutes is enough to drive most people bonkers. On top of that the game basically has no strategy to speak of. Its almost entirely luck and guessing. 
Ha, I can't even give it the comment a gaming buddy did who'd gotten conned into playing it a couple of months ago, "Its a perfectly acceptable 25% of a game." To me its about 10% of a game. I could have stood it if it had really only lasted 20 minutes. but at 54 minutes, regardless of who won it was utter tedium. I will never play this horrid little wart on the gaming hobby again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A fine short game, given that there is only so much you can do when each round consists of one decision to chose which card to discard, and then potentially another decision as to how to best use that card's effect.

People do seem to like it though, and it's a game that can have people laughing at misfortune (Baron with Countess only to see Princess, "wooops!" , the table laughs, the third player wins and you shuffle and play again) or the rewarding feeling of just "feeling it" and calling out the right card with the Guard card.

Ideal for just sitting down with a cup of coffee, you can talk about other stuff and have something to do for those who otherwise fidget and get restless at the idea of sitting and talking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
liked it. light fun
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Game in a Nutshell: Entrust characters to carry your love letter to the princess while using other characters to intercept your opponent's.

Played as: 3,4 player

Pros: It's incredible that such a unique experience could be had in a game that only has less than 20 cards and a few cubes. In only a few minutes, this game manages to bring deduction, bluffing, interaction, and loads of grins to the table. The form factor redefines portability. Very simple game to teach. I actually dig the theme and that they've incorporated a pretty rich story into it.

Cons: It isn't particularly deep and basic strategies will probably be boiled down after not a huge number of plays. Sometimes luck will put you in between a rock and a hard spot such that it's likely anyone's game. It's kind of embarrassing to get beat by first time players. 

Other: This is one of those games that is pretty much a must own filler. You can't argue with the price, and it really does offer a unique experience for a game of this one's length.

Best Use: Keep with your wallet and cellphone to take with you everywhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is for the Doctor Who re-themed copy that I made myself.

RATING: 4
I was told that "everyone loves this game," which I naturally took as a challenge. And so I was mildly disappointed when someone else in our group said he didn't love it.

Denied my opportunity to be a trendsetter, I settled for applying for citizenship in the newfound nation of people who don't love Love Letter (population two).

It works well and is simple to grasp even for a dumbass such as me. But I actually won, which came as a big surprise to all of us, so clearly it's broken or something.

If you like simple deduction games with a little luck, a little educated guesswork and cruel plays which can knock you out mere moments into a hand, go for it. It's pretty quick and may entertain you for 15-30 minutes.

Please note that our growing country, flooded as it is with the infrastructure demands of supporting two very cranky citizens, will be tightening admission requirements and levying a variety of infuriating fees and taxes for the privilege of joining us. Prepare yourself. Once we get to population 10, the anal probes begin.

RATING: 4
Got this to play with non-gamer family members over Thanksgiving. The game fell flat on each of the four plays, with different people, over the course of the week. This didn't resonate with any of the 8 people I played it with. One game had a break in the middle and half of the table didn't even want get back and to finish it.

Update:
Pulled it out with the other side of the family over Christmas. One sister in law would love it as a gift. They really enjoyed it.

Right now the game is 50/50 success rate, but probably won't get pulled out much.

Update 2: I have pulled this out with different people over the past 6 months.

Final analysis: While some other games can stand on their own feet, this game is one that is heavily dependent on who you play it with. It clicks with some people and falls flat with others. Very group dependent.

RATING: 6
Chris
Cory (Batman)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[microbadge=13314]

23-Jan-2014: I printed out one of the rethemes of this one to give it a try.  It had so much buzz about it but I wasn't really sure if it was worth picking up a copy with my limited need for completely non-solo games.

Anyway, this is a fun, mini-deduction game made up of only sixteen cards.  Each player has a hand of one card.  On your turn, you draw one then play one of the two you have.  Most cards have something special they can do so you can deduce what the other players are holding.  Either knock everyone else out of the game or be the player with the highest "ranked" card at the end to win a round.  Win a number of rounds to become the overall winner.

It plays super quickly.  The rules are easy to grasp.  And after a round or two, you should easily be able to remember what cards are in the game and what each can do.  It's definitely not a deep or thinky game, but it's pretty fun, with a short play time that almost anyone should be able to play.

Pretty cool idea for such a small game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* One of the foremost examples of the "microgame" craze
* Gameplay elicits difficult decisions and zero downtime
* Frequent plays would almost certainly lead to burnout
* Good for fans of card and deduction games and for any filler library
* Initial rating: [b]8/10[/b]

RATING: 9
16 cards, carry it on every trip. Fast rounds. Lucky draws can influence early leads, but especially with 4 players, players will deny each other the win. More skilled players will appreciate card counting and the complexity of when and how to bluff. Less skilled players will appreciate remaining close, and potentially being able "possum" their way to a win with good late game draws.

RATING: 7.75
This is a very quick and easy game available in many flavors (from princesses to Batman, to many others I would imagine)... but the basic mechanic remains the same. A series of cards of different rank, each with a specific ability/liability. The last player standing OR the player with the highest card wins - so the game is suitable for card-counting competitive crazies, all the way to novices. Quick, easy, and portable.

(Written on 12/27/17)

RATING: 8
Love Letter is super quick and straightforward. It's not the most basic of bluffing games, but it's not the most complicated either.

At the OT Board Game club, a group of students would play Love Letter almost every period, for the entirety of the period. If that's not a profound endorsement, then I don't know what is.

Sidenote: What's up with the princess? Seriously, she's, like, 8 feet tall.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I like Love Letter very much. As a friend said to me, either it is a genius game or totally mad. I think its a bit of both actually. In the games I’ve played, there have been loads of laughs.

AEG have done a great job of re-theming Love Letter into their Tempest series of games and from what I saw at Essen, it was very popular indeed and deservedly so.

Its not a serious game, but different to a lot of card games I’ve played. Its, fast and furious, surprising and down right mean. It looks great. The theme is thin but it works well enough. If you are looking for deep mechanics, and a strategic game, forget it. The mechanics are simple, you have some control over you destiny but not a lot so its pretty chaotic but I didn’t mind at all. Most of all its tremendously fun and a good laugh!

I would recommend this game without hesitation and would think that this is a great social game and great to use with non-gamers for a good time.

http://rivcoach.wordpress.com/2012/11/11/review-love-letter-from-aeg/

RATING: 7
Good first impression. Light. Thinky. Simple. Play the players and count the cards, but know that 1 card is not in the deck, so the game doesn't become deterministic. My only gripe initially is that it feels like the sort of game I'd like to play with 5 or 6 but it only seats 4.

4 seems much more interesting than 3.

After playing a session where the winner was the first to reach 3vp (rather than 4 or 5 as stated in the AEG rules) the game is much better this way, as a quick 15-minute filler.

After further experience with the game, I like it with 3 or 4 players, but I always play where the first player to 3 points wins. It's also not too bad as a 2-player game (though there are much better ones out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Letter ist ein feines, kleines Kartenspiel, dass bei uns immer mal wieder auf den Tisch kommt. Besonders mit Menschen, die eher selten Brettspiele spielen, kann man Love Letter sehr gut spielen. Ziel des Spiels ist es einfach,am Ende der Runde die Karte mit dem höchsten Wert (Prinzessin) auf der Hand zu haben, oder alle anderen Mitspieler "rausgeschmissen" zu haben. Dies geschieht durch die Eigenschaften der Karten, z.B. darf man die eben erwähnte Prinzessin nicht abschmeissen, wenn man sie einmal auf der Hand hat, bestimmte Karten, wie der Prinz können einen aber dazu zwingen. Außerdem kann man rausfliegen, wenn die Gegner wissen, welche Karte man auf der Hand hält. Hier istalso ein bisschen Täuschen und Bluffen angesagt. Dabei spielen sich die Runden so schnell und flott, dass man man auch mal mehrere Runden Love Letter am Stück spielt.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really simple, but fun to play. Often picked when we want a short, easily transportable filler. Or want to play in a small space at a restaurant/pub table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Letter has overtaken For Sale as the best 'filler' game I own.  It's incredibly fun, simple and plays quick.  Very luck dependant but there are just enough tactical choices that make you want to play it over and over again.  Incredibly clever little card game that contains only 16 cards! A must have! 

I also own the Kanai Factory version and whilst I prefer the art work, the Countess card makes the Tempest version, in my opinion, better because it adds an element of bluffing.  However, the card quality in this version is very poor in comparison.  Even if you don't like to sleeve cards, I would strongly suggest that you do for this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love Letter is the definition of a good filler- its exceedingly light and fast, has a large dollop of luck and a little twist of strategy and bluff. It can often feel like you are being played by the game rather then playing it but more sessions will reveal subtle strategies to the chaos that can be exploited by a wise player.

A game round can be over in just 5 minutes, although the AEG version I played is supposed to be played for several rounds until one player wins 4 times. I feel this may be too long for a game as simple as this, and would personally play it first to just 1 or 2 wins.

Its still a very fun little game considering its simplicity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the fastest games out there, Love Letter is a quick card game where the players look to play members of the Royal Court in the hope of being the last player left in a round and thus getting their Love Letter through to the Princess, who will reward you in kind. 

Win enough rounds and you take the game. 

Love Letter is a ridiculously simple design, which feels similar to games like Palasgefluster, except that this is even more streamlined. 

Player's take turns to play a card, representing a member of the court. Each character has a single line of text such as allowing the exchange of cards or allowing a player to guess the character held by another player. 

If guessed correctly, that player is knocked out of the round. 

So Love Letter requires a little deduction and some luck in order to give yourself the best shot. 

This was originally released with a Japanese Theme and has since spawned many custom variants. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
You are a suitor of the princess who must rely on various courtiers to carry your romantic letters to her as she has locked herself in the palace.

A hand management game of risk and deduction with player elimination.

RATING: 6
[b]Like:[/b]
-Extreme simplicity

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-Gets boring fast after repeated rounds

Easiest game ever?! Draw a card, play 1 of 2, do what it says, next! Even if you don't know all the cards (which is kinda required to get to the good stuff) there's a handy reference with all cards and effects. Cool game if you just want something to do that doesn't require a lot of room or brain power. However, it gets stale fast after a couple of rounds. I do appreciate its extreme simplicity though, and earns a point for that!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
主題:0.9
藉由將手上情書交給遊戲設定的角色，然後轉交給公主，但只要直接將情書交到公主手上，就直接出局，故事設定很有趣，角色的能力也能恰如其分，是個不錯的猜角色的遊戲!可以換成不同版本的角色也是遊戲設定很成功的地方。

美術:0.8
小品遊戲，眾多版本，每個版本都有自己的特色，也算是另類美術，但因為遊戲件數少，美術很難展現在整體遊戲上。

規則:0.8
簡單好教學，沒有太多例外，中規中矩，是個運氣4分、心理戰3分、邏輯刪去法3分的遊戲。

設置:1
本遊戲就是走好覺學好上手好設置的快速開局遊戲，體積小好攜帶，遊戲時間短，是個很好的墊檔遊戲。

路線:0.3
這個遊戲著重心理戰及觀看牌面的剩餘機率遊戲，運氣有一點，還可以小嘴砲猜心機，是個很棒的小品遊戲，但性質就是墊檔遊戲，所以遊戲路線不多，打久了就有點無聊。

互動:1
兩人至四人局都很熱鬧，雙方你來我往，毫無冷場，是個能藉由角色能力激發嘴砲的好遊戲，尤其很多自製版本，像是甄環傳版本。

個人:0.7 沒有好時機時，會想看它。(等人、時間不夠，剛好只帶這一款)  

朋友:0.7 玩起來還可以，但因為想玩的遊戲太多，常常輪不到它。

想玩:0.7 小遊戲等人時會想開看看，另外放在包包也很方便隨時玩!

收藏:0.7 
價格低，體積小，有多種不同版本，可以買一盒放在家裡墊檔用!只是耐玩性不高，或許有人不愛!
            
總分:7.6
講評:推坑利器、墊檔神兵、是居家旅行必備之桌遊!推薦給大家!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Fantastic micro game! I was skeptical about this game.  It seemed people were far too excited about it... but after finally picking up a copy, I can join in the excitement!  It's a great social deduction game that goes by quickly, yet has everyone working towards winning the game each round.  I played with 3 people, and it was excellent.  I think the game is perfectly small.  It has enough cards to make guessing the other characters card difficult, yet few enough cards that you can figure it out in just a few hands, often times 1 or 2 if you're lucky.  Each card is masterfully crafted with the perfect ability for game.  Nothing feels wasted or not thought out.

RATING: 4.4
It's strange I actually don't like the game when it is played by the rules. I have house ruled into the game a rule that, when there are only two people left, whoever is the last to draw, and there are no cards left, gets to guess who is in the love letter bag. If guessed correctly, they win, if not, the other person guesses and the point is awarded if they get it right. This is played of course, by not looking through the discard pile.

It changes the game completely and adds an element of memory to the game that keeps people really checking out for cards. Much better, and deeper in my opinion even though there is a slight luck element at the end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The golden hit of japanese micro-games. Lightning fast, super-fun and portable enough to take anywhere. Strong contender for the title of "king of filler". 

Kanai-Factory edition is the way to go if you ask me. The whimsy playing card-like artwork fits the mood of the game much better than the generic "videogame concept art" in the Tempest edition one does, plus: promo princesses!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In this card game, one is attempting to woo a princess with a love letter, and you want to prevent others from doing the same. There are 16 cards, with a numeric rank from 1 to 8, and each card has special abilities. For instance, there are 5 copies of the 1 card, which is a guard, and if you guess an opponent's card correctly, they are out for the round. Each round play cards to be the last one left, and you earn a cube. Play over multiple rounds, and the first one to four cubes wins.

It's a fun little filler. Yes, there is luck, there is some deduction involved, and it plays quickly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.25
The one of the best microgame
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
This game is VERY high on luck BUT not AS high on luck as you think it is the first time you play. You start to notice and understand subtle strategies in terms of logic of what's on the table and what must be in hands. There's a also a blackjack "card counting" element as far as playing the odds of what is likely or less likely to be in other people's hands.

The art is beautiful, the velvet bag is fun and convenient, the theme is there enough for how simple it is. This game is easy to teach, easy to play, you can play to as many points as you want or as few--the amounts they say in the rule book are arbitrary but good enough.

There's just enough luck, secrecy, decision making, and even bluffing. I think you need deeper bluffing with your behavior than just what you actually play to do really well.

The game is better with 3-4 but wasn't bad with 2. It's just less likely each game will be as dynamic. Many games that are 2-X players do better with more but it's especially so with this one. 

Because there are only 16 cards and they're reshuffled so often (one con to the game is the constantly shuffling), it's best to use sleeve protectors to keep the cards lasting.

I would put this in the same level of depth as Tsuro or Cthulhu dice only this one is probably better and has a bit more strategy and skill. 

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Great little game.  Managed to convince people who would never play anything but traditional card games (500, Uka, hearts, etc) to play this and they liked it.  Helps that the rounds are so quick.

You do however need to sleeve the cards to stop any chance of them getting marked.  I'd also suggest getting rid of the cubes (pointy corners mark the cards) for some flat plastic tokens.

Two player variant is ok for teaching people the rules but 3-4 players is the way to go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The rules are super simple

RATING: 8
Nice little game for the whole family.

Pros:
 - Fast setup & gameplay
 - Easy to teach
 - Nice bluffing elements and even though the game is very simple you can still strategize with the cards you play
 - EDIT: Great artwork

Cons:
 - Player elimination is bad in general but here the rounds are so fast that it doesn't bother you so much
 - Very luck driven game, all that it takes is the right cards at the right time (and half a brain...)
 - Only for 2-4 players, I would like this kind of game to be playable maybe up to 6 players at least.
 - I would not play Love Letter with only two players, haven't experienced it but the mechanics here seems to works better with more players.

RATING: 5
I appreciate the idea of making a full-fledged game out of a few cards and the nice, a little off-beat theme. In the end there are still very few decisions to be made and the overall winner is mostly decided by luck. 'Love Letter' lives from the suspense whether you will be caught with the wrong card in your hand or you can survive just long enough. Beyond that there is not much game here. Nevertheless, it can be a good choice for casual players due to the easy rules, theme, quick play and minimal space requirements.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
International love.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm not sure why Love Letter has gotten so much acclaim because I'm not sure its possible for a actual game to be contained in just 16 cards.

With each turn giving players a maximum of 2 cards in their hands the whole game amounts to a maximum 2 thoughts per turn: "Which card do I keep?" and possibly "Who do I pick on?" Then, while everyone else has their turn, all non-active players get to contemplate the question: "Why is this game called 'Love Letter' anyway?"

The fact that no one in our gaming group ever wanted to play a full game of Love Letter must say something about it. We'd play a few rounds and then just move on to something else, something better. 

At the very least, if this game interests you, get the Limited Edition with the original Japanese artwork. The Tempest version is plain ugly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not a fan of Love Letter in general, but if pressed to choose a version I would go with the Kanai edition as I prefer its woodcut-style art to this Tempest version

RATING: 8
A quite clever deduction game.  With the proper deducing you can figure what cards everyone has.  You can also be clever in your card play that will give you the chance to knock some players out of the game before the end.

There are a few cards numbered 1-7 with each one having a special power.  The game really lends itself to clever card play and deduction and it was my introduction to these shorter type card deduction games.

RATING: 7
Two-player rounds are lightning fast and totally hysterical. Four player rounds usually seem to last until the deck runs out, and have more actual game in them, including card counting.

Includes multiple card effects that require the players to be completely honest, so you might want to choose your opponents carefully.

Neither of the 2012 versions are boxed, which is a bit inconvenient. Very good card quality in the AEG edition, except my copy came with a marked deck. The boxed 2013 Pegasus edition is quite impressive: Wooden hearts and oversized AEG cards. The 2013 Kanai edition does not look bad either.

RATING: 7
A great little filler that will have everyone laughing.

Talk about simple, this game doesn't try for any gimmicks.  It's 16 cards, 8 types, and all you do is draw a card and play 1 of those cards.  And repeat till someone has a bunch of wins.

I usually hate simple games, but this game is so funny for some reason.  You have to play it, the game is like 8-10 bucks and you will be getting more hours out of this 15-30 minute game than your big hitters.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
16-card game with surprising depth! In this game, you're trying to win the affections of the princess before somebody else has the chance to. Combines luck, strategy, deduction, and even bluffing elements in a small, streamlined package for a fun, fast-paced gaming experience. Thanks to its small size and easy rule set, this is the perfect travel game for small groups. Be aware, the game is very luck-dependent with only two players, but strategy develops quickly as you add more people to the mix.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This is almost acceptable as a filler. There isn't much to it at all, but there are a couple cool elements that begin to reveal themselves after a round or two. Can be funny, especially if you're as forgetful as I am (I saw someone's hand, then used the guard on him and totally guessed wrong... :blush:). It can also be utterly dry and boring depending on the card draw and the player base.

There is really no game here. No, it's not a bluffing game or a deception game or a memory game. It's a crappy game. Overhyped for sure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
"It would like to be, but it can't"

Love letters is a game which initially surprises everybody. With very few rules and even less cards with easy abilities you are able to build up interesting and unexpected situations, which make fun. Deciding what to play is very easy and often straightforward, game is strongly balanced thanks to the fact that it is strongly luck driven in several matches (central limit theorem effect...).
But sooner or later it will happen that you have the Princess in hand since the beginning of some consecutive games and you will start to count how many real DECISIONS are you taking. For me it was 11 decisions in 12 matches (of 4 rounds each)... wow! All the rest were either mandatory (other 36 card decisions and about 15 players to target) or totally random (says a role when all are still available). And the 11 I took were only between TWO options!
Honestly, this is the decision level of tic-tac-toe! I can easily program a computer WITHOUT AI to play in my place, buzzing for my attention whenever a real decision is going to be taken (every 5 minutes).

Game can be improved if cards are made a little more complicated or maybe 3 in hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Best with 4, Family (23)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]Cockroach Poker killed this game for me and my family. While an okay micro game, it doesn't offer any of the banter and humor of a game like Cockroach Poker so it quickly fell out of favor in our house.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]- Great cafe/restaurant game, 16 cards and some cubes.
- Each round plays very quick, a whole game takes less than 15 minutes.
- Great family game that introduces bluffing.[/i]

RATING: 5
In general, the mechanics of this hidden-role card game are quite clever. It isn't without its flaws, however. Certain cards are either useless or over-powered at times, so I think the role interactions could have used some tweaking. I'm not sure the game has a lot of replay value either. But for the most part, it is an enjoyable diversion that does require some tactical shredness.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Surprisingly more-ish. Not sure I'd want to play it each week, as each hand is much the same as the previous one, and you play quite a few hands, but the hands go so quick, that even a quick exit on one hand doesn't leave you out of the game for more than a minute or so. There's a decision to make with each new card, trying to work your way into a position to win the hand. There's a deduction / elimination type aspect - what cards are out, been seen, what might he have left in hand. It's like lots of little Cluedo's, one after each other, with a little risk-taking as well when you play a higher card and keep a lower card. It's a solid filler, easy to teach and play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Blah. But at least there are several rounds, so if you get wiped out early by a blind guess or by metagaming, you can feel a little less frustrated (than in Coup)

What I like:
- Quick, portable, minimalistic
- Surprisingly interesting game for its size

What I don't like:
- I'm not a fan of bluffing/deduction games
- Still not clear how much skill there is.

Super clever game design. It's a nice quick filler, but I think it would wear out its welcome at about 30 minutes. I think the 1.2 weight is about right. I might go 1.4.

RATING: N/A
R
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great for what it is.

I mean I can see the cons. Lot's of luck involved, little strategy and you get the feeling that sometimes the game plays itself, phalocratic and girlish at the same time, but...

...somehow the game manages to be fun for me and everyone I played with. Just silly, lazy fun with a pinch of thinking (what cards are still in play, and how to manage every situation).

Super portable, super light, super quick rounds, super cheap, super easy to explain (people easily intimidated by rules and complexity will find paradise), lots of socializing. 

I personaly feel a pokerish aspect, when I learn what faces each player of my gamegroup make or tactics they use when they got certain cards, and then name the cards with a guard, without having any obvious clue and make my opponents mad. Great feeling!

Play it anywhere, with everyone, anytime. Thumbs up. 

Get it and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EL8e2ujXe8g!

(Wife's Point of View: She doesn't love it, she just likes it, but it's so fast, light and comfortable that is always enjoyable for her. Unfortunatelly I belive it's a bad 2 player game)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very simple filler where you try to be the last person with a card in your hand. Each turn you draw a card and then play a card. Each card has a different power and you value. Using your action you want to have others discard their card and therefore be out of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple filler card game that looks more random than it is at first glance. The more cards that get discarded, the more information is left about the potential cards that the players are holding, this has the effect of speeding up the end game and increasing the skill that is involved in making decisions.

Always fun to play and somehow it always seems to end with the scores very close.

RATING: 5
[color=blue]Playtime: 1-30+ minutes[/color]

Comment: Not nearly as good as the original design, the changes to this game put it down a few notches for me. It's fast, fun and mostly luck based. My biggest complaint for this game is the 4 player rules. It takes far too damn long to actually complete this if you have a player try to hit 4 wins. Sometimes it's quick, other times this turns into a 30-45 minute game. It's not fun after about 20 minutes.

[color=green]Optimal Player Count: 4
Plays well with all player counts.[/color]

[color=purple]Extras: Sleeved in FFG silverline sleeves.[/color]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Playtime: 1-30+ minutes.

Comment: The original and slightly different version than the Tempest one. I really like how the Minister plays and I really like the card left in hand when the deck runs out versus what you have in front of you. It's slightly more strategic that way and opens up a different layer of depth.

Edit: These subtle changes really mix up the game. We love this version as compared to the tempest one. Our go to game when it gets really late and we don't quite want to go to bed yet.

Optimal Player Count: 4
Plays well with all player counts.

Extras: Sleeved in FFG silverline sleeves.

RATING: 8.2
This game is one of the quickest games you will ever play. It takes about 2 or 3 minutes and it's over, but it is a LOT of fun. I only play this game in between two longer games as a bit of a break, it's not ideal to start a game night because every game will seem even longer after this, but it is great to break up a couple of longer and arguably better games with something like this to keep the games coming. This is a lot of fun though, very easy to learn and play and a nice micro or mini-game to have around.

BGG SS 2014.  So much fun.  We play this while brewing beer and it's great that we don't have to sit down to play.  The rounds are quick, and so is a total game.  You only have 2 cards in your hand on your particular turn, so there isn't too much strategy (until you get towards the end of the round and you're trying to count cards, guess what card is burried, and what is in the other player's hands based on what they're laying down).
