RATING: 8
$11

Goal Met :star::star::star::star::star: $1 or less per play

This is a really good filler to fill in the gap in between games or to play with non-gamers. My parents had a blast playing this game. 

I still think Biblios is the better filler for me simply because it is more random than Love Letter. After 3 straight games tonight it does feel a bit of same-y. I would like to try it with 4 players. I don't feel this with 3 games of Biblios. Randomness does help on the re-playability here.

This game strikes a balance between memory, deduction, and a bit of bluffing/gambling. ;) It is a solid game with a dash of luck.

I don't worry about meaningful decisions because it is so light of a game. My first game with parents did run for 45mins since they were struck with AP.

RATING: 6.5
This is a fun little card game that is perfect to take with you when going out for drinks with friends. The rules are very simple and easily picked up by even non-gamers. The only weakness of the game is that it is very dependent on the luck of the draw. There are a few card combinations that, when playing with even moderately observant opponents, almost guarantee that you will lose. That said, it's this randomness that can make matches surprising and memorable.

RATING: 4

RATING: 8
This is a blast to play. There aren't that many (non-obvious) decisions, but at the same time there's plenty going on. The reading and deduction make it less quick than other light games such as No Thanks!, but there's an element of secrecy that adds tension and theme and laughs that other games this simple don't usually have.

It's a wonderful design. I just might have to carry the cards in my wallet at all times, since I'd play this game any time, anywhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After playing the game I was left wondering how could I apply deduction?

I think this aspect will only become apparent after playing the game several times, because it seems that the only way to read someones choice of play/body language is to know the deck well and the consequences of the text effects. For such a simple game the textual terrain and card tracking is a hurdle just to get to the satisfying exercise of trying to read your opponent, especially for a elimination game.

RATING: N/A
Quick Deduction/Guessing game - Be the last one alive or be holding the highest card when the deck runs out to "win" the round to earn "tokens of affection".  Use abilities (on either of the two cards you will be holding on your turn) to peek at or switch hands, protect yourself for a round, or use a guard to try and knock out an opponent.

RATING: 10
What a breath of fresh air! There are so many ways this game shouldn't work. It only has 16 cards, eight of them unique. It has player elimination, often before you've even played a card. It offers few choices, let alone meaningful ones. But I've already played it 25 times, and I don't think I'm ever going to get tired of teaching it to a new group (in 30 seconds) and seeing them erupt into hilarity within a minute flat. Pure joy in an envelope. 

[Brief note on versions: I prefer the art and rules of the Japon Brand original, but others favour the AEG version in one or both aspects. YMMV, but it doesn't really matter]

RATING: 5
Does not actually play well with 2, as your decisions are simply which one of 2 cards to play each turn  -- and some card plays are obvious losers or blocked by the effects of other cards, so you can actually have no decision on many turns in 2 player. This is pretty close to random draw and would get a 1 rating.

However the addition of a 3rd or 4th player adds the crucial choice of which player to apply that effect to, which makes a damn fine game with a shocking amount of emergent strategy, this probably deserves a 10 rating.

So, I'm gonna average those scores and give it a 5 overall.

RATING: 7

There is a fair amount of luck involved in each round, so it's best to play several round in a row like the rules suggest.

RATING: 7
Love Letter is a really nice filler game. The strategy is fairly trivial and there is a substantial amount of luck in terms of the cards one draws. That said, games move along quickly (although I think the best thing is to decide beforehand that the winner is the person who gets 3 tokens of affection first) and is very easy to teach and learn.

For about $5 and with just 16 cards, Love Letter is a unique game and totally worth it.

RATING: 7
Love Letter is a simple game that can be very intense, especially in later rounds. The nice thing about this game is what you can 'deduce' about other player hands, making it satisfying when you correctly call what card they have. The game feels nicely balanced, with the 'value' of cards being a nice equaliser to the abilities that they grant. The theme, while not the most prominent while playing, is pretty interesting and ties well to the different card mechanics. I would recommend playing with the full 4 people, as having less does hamper the enjoyment somewhat. Simple, clean fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I first played this as a quick game at the end of board game night with a friend, without either of us having played it before, and it was nicely straightforward to pick up. 

Thoughts after this first play-through: 

* I enjoyed the mechanics of the game, which I imagine allow you to play quite strategically. Certainly by the end of a couple of rounds It was fun as a 2-player, though I'd definitely be keen to play it with 3 or 4 players as well.

* The "love letter" aspect is of course fairly arbitrary, in that using the same game mechanics while changing the motivation & some of the character names would result in an essentially identical gaming experience. But consequently it doesn't really matter one way or the other; it's a framing story to hang the gameplay on rather than being absolutely essential to the game.

* Given the small size/ease of picking up the rules/relative inexpensiveness of the game, I'm definitely inclined to pick up a copy.

RATING: 8
Really great little game. Easy to teach and quick to play. I made a custom Monster High theme version and have played this with my daughter since she was 6. She absolutely loved it and played it practically daily (so much so we have gone through 2 sets of cards and now have a set of plastic ones). Now she often asks to play the normal version. Had I started her on this though I doubt she would have ever persisted with it. I am always trying to find games that I can play with my young kids. This is the only board game I have played with any of my kids at that age that we both find equally fun. I haven't played it myself, but the "Letter's to Santa" version might be good for trying to get young kids into the hobby.

RATING: N/A
An enjoyable "draw a card, play  card" game that is light and somewhat silly. Each card type has a special power and you get to try to be Last Man Standing in your attempt to seduce the Princess by delivering a letter to her. Don't overthink it. 

The AEG rules of playing to 3 cubes can create a game that takes 30 minutes, which is crazy. Play a couple hands and call it a day. If someone wants to be crowned Ultimate Winner of Love Letter, you're playing with the wrong people.

RATING: 8.5
Pros:
* Extremely portable
* Nothing to setup
* Plays well with 2

Cons:
* Doesn't play as well with 2 as with 3+

Variants:
* When playing with 2 people in a restaurant, use a single scoring token (e.g. a salt shaker) and place it between both players. After each round, move the token one "space" closer to the winner. When the food arrives, the winner is the person to whom the token is closest.
* When playing with 2, allow targeting of a player who played a Handmaid but ignore the effect.

= 2013-07-26 - R:8.5

We played this on the side of a hill. The game needs to little space, we were able to play by keeping the discard pile on one person's lap and the draw deck on the other's. We've played it at parks, in restaurants, on the bus. And unlike other games that might sacrifice gameplay in order to play in so little space, this one is actually FUN.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
September 2017: Gave it to a friend. Downgraded from 5 to 3. There is no long-term replayability. At least it's short.

2014-05-13: Update. A 5. This game is like cigarettes. It gives your hands something to do. A bit addictive, and probably not good for your gaming health in large amounts.

The take-that is more tolerable here than in other games because often there is a risk of being nasty towards your opponent.

2013-03-27: Update, from 7 to 6. This is surprisingly not newbie-friendly. In order to enjoy this game at its full potential, an ultra-light deduction game with a hint of take-that, players have to understand how all the cards work together. Newbies don't realize this, assume that Love Letter has too much luck, and give up quickly on it.

Update, from 5 to 7.

Much, much better with 4. A lot of clever ways to deduce what you're opponents are holding.

This is a filler for gamers because the deduction elements are actually not that straightforward.

A lot of fuck you opportunities, from opponents and from the luck of the game. It's hilarious to have the game itself eliminate you from the round.

==================

Not very good at all with two -- at that number, it's a game you laugh [b]at[/b], not [b]with[/b].

There's so much luck in this game that the deduction and bluffing is not noticeable.

RATING: 6
Love Letter is utterly adorable.  A Fun 5 minute game for 3-5 players in a 15 card deck.  

Totally accessible by non-gamers and super gamers alike. Love Letter is a bit like Poker: each round's results is highly dependent on the luck of the draw... However there's enough room for strategic thinking that over the course of multiple back to back rounds skilled players can pull ahead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game is a gateway to deduction and "bluffing" games such as Coup. It is so far the easiest setup and quickest game.

At first, it is lots of fun, but your group quickly realizes that most of it is really blind luck. It is deduction game of Go Fish with the player elimination of Coup.

Not much too this game though. There are some frustrating times where you get stupid card combinations like: 2 Barons (B-Baron, we call it), King + Princess (Regicide, we call it), and other very sub-optimal hands.

It often winds up a 50/50 of the burned card and the one the opponent has.

We quickly started playing Coup instead of Love Letter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Short and sweet. I really like playing between other games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Description: Light, simple, deduction, bluffing, card game with player elimination.
Number of players: 2 to 4. Best with 4.

Impression: The game is a blast for what it contains. It's a brilliant design by Seiji Kanai, who made an exciting bluffing, competitive, deduction game with only 16 cards, which later became his signature attribute for many other games. The theme is cute, but the game play is quick and fun and it goes - draw a card, play a card, apply effect.  
Plays quick; Many different outcomes for a game with 16 cards. Poker-like outplays. Rewarding wild guesses.  Buy not so good with 2 players.

RATING: 7.5
A very basic set of rules and components: each turn you draw a card and then discard one of the two cards in your hand, performing its effect (e.g. peeking at an opponent's card, swapping cards with an opponent, etc.). At the end of the round, the player with the highest rated card earns a point. Thematic filler.

RATING: 8.2
[b]11 plays in:[/b]
Kathryn and I have played this a few more times now and are still enjoying the game. It is a light game that doesn't overstay it's welcome and is fun to pull out every few days.

I threw it in my backpack over a vacation last week and we got 5 plays in while on the go. The small footprint made it a great way to pass the time while waiting for a show to start or our table to become available at dinner time.

Still haven't played with with more than two, but would love to do so.

[b]4 plays in:[/b]
Played a handful of games and my wife gives it the thumbs up so it should hit the table at least a few more times.

This game is very quick to teach, which I find helps immensely in getting a game played with my wife or family. It is also pretty short which means if someone doesn't like it, it's over soon!

Playing a 2 handed game to 7 points our matches after the learning game have taken 15-20 minutes. A round probably takes us a little over a minute on average with an occasional round ending on the first play, but some probably taking close to 2 minutes.

I get a kick out of being eliminated on the first play with a lucky Guard guess, etc (happens infrequently enough to hold its charm.) Also always great when one of us makes a dumb-dumb play to lose a round. For example, using King and trading the other player a Guard. Oops!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I bought this to supplement our supply of simple party games that can play relatively quickly. It has been a reasonable success. Each turn players draw a card, then either play it or keep it and play the card they previously held. The objective is to get to the bottom of the deck without being knocked out of the round and holding the highest value card possible.
Simple yet effective, the game is partly about bluffing, partly about reading opponents, partly about probability, and a lot about luck.
It is fun to play and easy to learn and we had it over in less than thirty minutes on a first play so it definitely fits the party game slot I had hoped for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Initial rating after 1 play.  Enjoyable light and quick game.

RATING: 7
DIY和Z
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was a big disappointment to me the first time I played it - while of course I wasn't expecting a deep strategy game, or anything pretending to be one, I was still disappointed in how few decisions there were and how random it all seemed (and how you can sometimes be eliminated early on through absolutely no fault of your own). But I have warmed to the game much more in subsequent plays - it's a great little end-of-night game, still pretty random but with some nice deduction and bluffing elements. And it's certainly quick and gets you talking.

There is no question in my mind that Lost Legacy is a much better implementation of the same concept (the deduction elements are bigger there, and it feels less random), but Love Letter is still a good game for what it is. And dare I say that I even enjoyed this as a 2p game, the one time we tried it, even though it's then more or less completely random and nothing to do with holding on to high cards, it's all about eliminating the other player before they do the same to you...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very clever light filler...an awful lot of fun for such a small game.

RATING: N/A
[b]16 cards @ 63mm W x 89mm H[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love love letter. It's so simple to play in a few minutes with new players, really easy for children, no explaining needed, I mean the instructions you need at any point are literally on the cards that you hold in your hand. That's it. It really is as simple as can be and it is impossible to have a quicker set up.
While it obviously has a large luck element each iteration or hand is so quick that you can play several times to even it out.
My only tiny quibble is with the "story" rather than the ludic element of the game. It makes no sense. It doesn't interfere with the play but if you are sending letters to the princess how can you be the princess? I get how the handmaid would protect the princess but not the majority of cards in a hand etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I normally lean to more heavy and strategic games, but Love Letter is an absolute blast to play! It's a very light game that you can teach in about two minutes and play in about half an hour. Who wins in a two-player game is entirely based on luck, so I strongly suggest you play this one with three or four players. If you're looking for a fun filler game, I cannot think of a better game for you than Love Letter!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
7.1.13 Initial rating was a 7 for this game. We all enjoyed it and it took a bit to get the feel. After more plays I have bumped this up to an 8.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is quirky, in a good way. The rules suggest a game with barely any substance--a game of War with character abilities. After so many plays, I still do not see the connection with sending a love letter to the princess.

However, the more I played, and moreso with the same group, I noticed that a fun little metagame began to develop. The cards soon became more of a medium through which players express their behaviors, and the games evolved into lightning-quick romps of bluffing and gloating and gawking...with the right group. Therein lies the rub. The "right group" of players, those willing to roll with the prevalent punches of luck and take-that, can breathe life into what is, in truth, a fairly abstract card game. The contrary group will make this experience fall face-flat. A solid filler entry.

(+) Simple yet offering surprising amount of depth in gameplay.
(+) High player interaction.
(+) Quick rounds that complement the development of a metagame.

(-) Hefty amount of luck involved.
(-) Player elimination is frequent, and encouraged. This may not sit well with some.
(-) The liveliness of the game seems to hinge heavily on group attitudes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A nice game to fill in the gaps between larger games or to wrap-up a game night.  With only 16 cards and a few tokens, doesn't need that much room to play, so has the advantage of portability as well as the ability to play while in line or on an airplane.

That said, much of the game is based upon the social psychology of the players as one is trying to deduce with limited information (only a few cards played per round) what other players might be holding so as to position one's self to win the round.  That said, there is also a splash of luck as the cards dealt sometimes can't be overcome (eg. receiving the minister in the Kanai edition and drawing a high rank card on your first turn), so players will have to deal with that as well.

Not a game to play repeatedly, but on occasion to avoid the limits card play getting too stale (which is why I have rated it a 6 instead of a 7 - need to be in the right mood to play this one.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.4
Probably the lightest, quickest game I own. The game itself is a deck of 13 cards, each card giving you a specific power or benefit when using it. All you have to do is have the highest ranking card when the game ends. Each game takes 15-30 minutes. Is it fun? Oh yes, and there are a few tricks which you will learn only after a few plays. Did I mention it's also hilarious at times when people screw up? We tend to laugh a lot when we play this game.

RATING: 6
Love letter has to be the most fun, when compared to what the components are.  This game is not even the size of a Full deck of cards.  Only  sixteen cards and some cubes. You play as different characters trying to get letters to the queen. You are trying to deduce through social clues and revealing other cards who the other players have in their hands. 

Pros: Extremely Short game, Highly interactive Deduction., Portable and can be played anywhere.

Cons: Extremely short game. Player elimination.

RATING: 8
"Love Letter" is a card game with deduction and elimination gameplay. The game is played over several fast rounds so players aren't eliminated for long. I think it is a fun game accessible to casual gamers. 

My only complaint with Love Letter is that it lacks some flexibility when it comes to the number of players. It is designed for a maximum of four players and is best played with four players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love Letter is a fun, light game with a very small footprint (in playtime, rules weight, room needed to play,...). It's up to the task, whether you want to play it at the start of a gaming session (to get in the mood, or even to introduce new players to each other), in between games, or as a light-hearted laughter-filled cooldown after a heavier (tenser) game. You can play it with experienced as well as occasional gamers. The game just clicks with people (there's quite a few people who bought it after I introduced them to the game).

This game made me realize something: it's not bad rules or poor components that truly make or break a game. It's the people you play it with. They're the most important aspect of a good gameplay experience.

Finally, these are my thoughts on sleeving the cards. Since there's only 16 of them, they'll get worn pretty evenly. This means that you probably won't recognize a card by its damaged back. While I wouldn't go as far as buying sleeves for this game specifically, if you have some spares lying around don't hesitate to use them for Love Letter (that's what I did).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
A very fun game with a tiny footprint and a refreshing minimalist design. This game should be in everyone's collection, though once you've had it a while it shouldn't come out nearly as often.

Has the potential to be a lot of fun if you're playing with people who actually are enthusiastic about the game.

RATING: 7
Played quite a bit of this one; find it best with 4 players and can't be bothered to play 3 player games any-more. 

Still sometime play a 2 player variant (2 cards in hand) - which works fairly well as a time waster, but has very limited tactics/strategy.

Best with new people, easy to grasp rules - although going over all the cards usually takes some time - a lot more than you would expect.

7 - as it suffers slightly in its group size - would be a perfect light party game, but there are better 4 player games to play.

Bonus points for simplicity, and if it was less reliant on text it would be perfect. Playing with my family (when travelling back home) involves translating all the cards on a sheet of paper every time (which takes time again).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
OK, this is probably the simplest game I own.  I tend to break it out often when playing with new gamers because of how simple, but unique it is.  Players only ever have two cards, and they pick one to play to give them a special ability in trying to eliminate the other players that round.  Guess a card, trade, discard... If you are the last player in, you win the princesses favor for now (or a letter or something like that)!  There are many different versions of this game with different IP's that would fill in for this just fine though.  If you are interested, find one of the other themes you like more, like Batman or LOTR.

Dec 2012 Order from Santa
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Holy overhyped, Batman!

So, on the very first round I was seated 2nd, and was out of the round before I had a chance to even play. As I immediately said to my friend sitting next to me: "That's a problem."

There were times you knocked people out thanks to clever deduction. And there were just as many times you knocked people out by blind luck.

For a game of this weight and length I'm actually okay with the amount of luck. That doesn't mean I want to play it again, though...

Coup is mostly bluffing and some deduction. Love Letter is almost no bluffing, and mostly deduction and luck. I much prefer Coup.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
What a waste of $10. 

This game involves virtually no thought. "Do I play this card or this card?" is the deepest thinking that you can have. Often, you are forced to play one card. Often, you can lose a round without even playing a card. "Do you have a..." "Yes" "I win the round" is a common first turn. 

Summary:
- The game plays itself
- It has no difficult choices
- If you have a strategy, it probably won't matter
- even the theme is lame

And I like luck in games too!

RATING: 9
The game is easy to play and can be a short game or a long game.  The play itself is fast.  The rules are simple and the cards explain themselves.  Last one holding the Princess or the one who has the highest card wins the round.  First player to 5 (or 7 in the batman version) is the one who sent the love letter to the Princess (or captured all the villains). I keep this one in my purse for game playing on the go; however, I do recommend sleeving the game as who knows what nasty grubby stuff can get on the cards.

RATING: 7
A quirky microgame which has some clever interactions between cards that reveal themselves as the game goes on. It's true that for a large part of the game, the cards play you as having 2 cards in hand does not make for a lot of decisions, but there is also quite a lot of bluffing and deduction involved. Given the short playing time per round, it's a good compromise. Playing it until the recommended number of wins does make it run a little long though.

RATING: 8.5
2014: 8, almost a 9. Yup, the game deserves the hype I'd heard. It's pretty great for being a such a small, light game.  Was able to teach the game very quickly and everyone's enjoyed it.

Many comparisons made between this and Coup.  Very different games that generate very different emotions. I prefer Coup, but Love Letter is just so elegant and digestible for non-gamers and "just wanna hang out" people. Both games have a role and a place in your collection.

RATING: N/A
Munchkin Loot Letter Variant
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is perfect for getting non-gamers into board/card games. The guys that I regularly play with bring their girlfriends to our game nights. The girls don't want to play our usual games because they look too complicated (too many cards, too many pieces, too many rules, too long, etc). The simplicity of Love Letter (and possibly the theme) always draws them in. 
The cards are well-balanced, simple enough for non-gamers to understand but the mechanics still provide a challenge to veteran gamers. Also, the rounds are quick and we can play an entire game in well under an hour. 
One thing that always gets negatively commented on are the tokens. We just have little, red cubes made of wood. Maybe heart-shaped tokens or printed coins or something more substantial and in line with the theme would be appreciated. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A few simple tricks, but don't expect real depth here. A 16 card game may be clever, but it ends up being just what it sounds like -- a 16 card game. It is not magically somehow deep.

Past that, it's a cute and fun novelty. Good as a filler option if you adjust the game length, but it can potentially run too long if the wins are spread out and you play to the official victory condition. Stopping anytime should be no problem though; additional rounds don't build on previous ones, and the bluffing elements are so light that nothing changes much game to game.

(3 Design + 2 Enjoyment)

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Very random and no real strategy/tactics. Also very bad if you get eliminated in the 1st round. 

People say there are bluffing in this game, but the few times I have played, there aren't any and this game isn't really about bluffing to begin with. 

Each turn you draw a card, does what it says and _hope_ you kill someone or don't die. When it's not your turn, there's pretty much nothing you can do. There's no strategy or tactic you need to think about. If you are targeted by another player when it's not your turn, the game doesn't offer you any way to react to it. 

Very bland game. People say there are strategy to this game, I just don't see any.

RATING: 7
If you want a two-player deduction game, try Coup. 

One example: A few of the cards feel less powerful in a two-player game, such as the Handmaidens. The rounds are more likely to end due to special abilities so trying to hold a Princess/Countess card in your hand doesn't seem like a good strategy.

If you want a three- and four-player deduction game, this one is very entertaining. Trying to read through everyone's supposed Poker faces and observing/analyzing the cards played on the table keeps you on your toes. Unlike two-player, rounds usually play through until the end and eliminating other players feels like a small victory in itself.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Complexity: Easy
Players: 2-4

Very simple deduction game.  At the beginning of each turn, players draw a card which depicts one of eight different roles, then play a card.  The last player standing is the victor.  If there are two or more players remaining after the deck runs out, then the person with the highest ranking card in their hand wins.  The major selling point of this game is its extreme portability and ease of teaching.

As an aside, we bought a bunch of these and gave them to our wedding party at our wedding.  It was fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A very quick and easy to learn game. The artwork on the cards is really well done, and it's fun trying to figure out what each player is holding.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
2-3 plays at MACE

What a [i]brilliant[/i] little game! It reminds me, unsurprisingly, of [thing=2051]Pico[/thing] and [thing=606]Pico 2[/thing]: games with tiny little decks of cards that play quickly and are all about getting into your opponent's head. This game, though, has a bit more randomness and a lot more flavor. Instead of just playing numbered cards, you're playing people with special powers. Instead of playing 2 mirror hands, you play several (winning score varies by player count: 4, 5, or 7 hands) drawing from a single, randomly shuffled deck. The differences make this game much less an exercise, and much more fun. All in just 16 cards and some cubes!

[b]--- Summary ---[/b]
Shuffle the 16 cards (numbered 8, 7, 6, 5x2, 4x2, 3x2, 2x2, 1x5) and deal 1/player. In a 2-player game, remove 1 from the round unseen, and place 3 face up in display.

On your turn, draw a card from the deck, then play a card in front of you (on top of any previously played cards). Each card has a different power, and may result in a player being eliminated from the round. Continue play till only 1 player remains: score a VP (cube).

Repeat playing hands until one player has 1 + (12/n) cubes = winner!

RATING: 7
I was incredibly surprised by this game.  I usually don't like small, light games.  I like games with a lot of meat and depth.  For this reason I don't have many short time fillers.  I was certain I was going to be bored with this game which only includes 16 cards.  I was very wrong, in the category of games that only fill 10-20 minutes (including teaching and setup time) this may be my favorite game.

It is so simple and elegant in its design yet incredibly interesting and fun.  Plus the game just has that charm that makes you feel good when playing and ready to shuffle up and play another.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This rating will drop but our first game of this was just hilarious.  This is a very light weight game but was flat out enjoyable to play.  My daughters played the game using fake British accents and the comedic commentary was side splitting.  There are decisions but you don't have to think to hard leaving you free to goof around.  My favorite moment was when I had to discard the Countess and everyone knew I had the Princess.  My daughter put down the Guard, and everyone else said bye-bye Daddy, and she said in her best British accent, "Father, I assassinate your..... King!" and my oldest shouted "What!" and I said "Nay Nay" with everyone rolling in laughter.  For under $10 you cannot go wrong.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Surprisingly, Love Letters is a really fun game for the Light category! I like playing it.  It's more a simple deduction game as you "action" one of the two cards in your hand every round (total cards in the game are only 16 cards I think).

It's a great family game especially for younger kids maybe teens (who can read and deduce a bit).

There are times where you're really just forced to action your "play" for the round either to avoid losing or because the card the situation at that moment triggers one of your cards to "require" to "play" your next card out accordingly (meaning you don't have a choice).  Can gets repetitive quickly if you overplay it. Really meant for a "quicky" every once in awhile not as your main event for the whole evening of repetitive play.

Yet the game is still fun if you keep in mind how simple 
and Light it really is.

It's ingenius and so elegant! Bravo to the creators!!

RATING: 8
A very good micro game.  It deserves its reputation.  It is easy to teach and can be played quickly.  It tends to get repetitive plays.  The only thing that I can see hurting it, is that it is not truly deep.  There are optimal strategies for a hand in a circumstance and because the hands are few and the relevant circumstances fewer, it will get to a point where its depth is exhausted.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
Great game. One of my favorites. Perhaps it will decline over time as the game gets played out, but I can't help but be impressed with how much fun can come out of just 16 cards! When you are first learning the rules it comes off as a simplistic game with 100% luck. There is certainly luck involved but the strategy is richer than you think. Even though you never have more than 2 cards in your hand, there is much to think about. Although it doesn't have the depth and length to go beyond just a filler game, I often play it between heavier games. In fact it's a great finisher. It's like the dessert of card/board games. It's short and sweet. 

Artwork- 8
Ease to Teach- 10
Fun- 10
Mechanics- 9
Replay Value- 7
Strategy- 8
Theme- 9

61/70= 87.1%

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Quick playing deduction game. Players are each dealt a card, each depicting one of eight different characters, and on their turn draw another one. From the two cards they now hold they choose one to play, which will interact with an opponent in some way. For instance, the guard allows the player to try and guess an opponent's card, which would mean they would have to discard it, the handmaid means you're immune to opponents' cards for a turn, the king allows you to exchange your hand with an opponent, and so forth. the winner is the either the only person not to have discarded a card, or the person in possession of the highest value card once the deck has run out. This is a fun deduction game with a large proportion of luck, but due to the quick play time and if not taken too seriously is definitely worthy of consideration as a 'filler'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A simple card game where players have 1 card in hand and draw 1 on their turn. Each card has a value of 1-8 and a special ability associated with that card. On their turn players play 1 card and follow the ability as outlined on the card. Through a process of strategy, reason, and deduction you are attempting to eliminate players from that particular hand. The player who wins a predetermined amount of hands (usually 4 or 5) is the victor. This game is best with 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A simple card game where players have 1 card in hand and draw 1 on their turn. Each card has a value of 1-8 and a special ability associated with that card. On their turn players play 1 card and follow the ability as outlined on the card. Through a process of strategy, reason, and deduction you are attempting to eliminate players from that particular hand. The player who wins a predetermined amount of hands (usually 4 or 5) is the victor. This game is best with 4 players.

RATING: 8.5
Note: This rating is based on the Japon Brand version rather than the AEG version. Because of the AEG rules changes (and only very slightly because of the new artwork) I'd rate the AEG version a full point lower.

Love letter is a marvellously clever little game with a huge amount of fun, choices and great design packed in to 16 cards.

An absolute gem of a game and a perfect example of a design with no padding added (take note FFG!).

Okay, so it's moderately luck based, but I don't care; and when it takes 5 minutes, you shouldn't either. Stunning.

RATING: 7
Alright, this game is great fun, and for only 16 cards, and can be taught in about 2 minutes, and can be played in about 10 minutes.  Uh, this one is a winner.

After a bit of time, it kind of loses its luster a bit.  Because it's so small, nearly every interaction is seen after only a few games, then you're just kind of going through the motions at that point.  It's still fine mainly because it's so short, but it just doesn't have enough oomph to keep it around or make it a staple.

Got caught in the hype.
I don't mind playing it but there are multiple games on same (or more) time period that I prefer.

Pros:
-Quick to play.
-Easy to teach.
-Some room for misdirection plays.

Cons:
-Seems too random.
-More metagame than game (which I don't enjoy much).
-Random Guard assassinations first turn are just unfun.

RATING: 9
At less than $10 on Amazon, there is no reason for you not to own this game.  It plays fast (20 min or less), has excellent theme and gameplay (woo that Princess and knock out the competition!), and comes in a travel friendly/aesthetically pleasing felt bag.  Everyone I have ever seen play this game has fallen in love with it.  The race for the hand of the princess is simply intoxicating.  

I'm giving this a 9 because after countless amounts of plays, I am still not tired of it. Go buy this game.  Right now.  Not owning it is simply unforgivable.

RATING: 8
Love letter is a wonderful, light, fun game, but only if you have 4 players. At 3, it's okay, and at two, there are many other games that are better. However, at 4 players, it's portable and can be played anywhere (even on an airplane!), has a lot of interaction between players, is quick (rounds can take between 2 and 8 minutes). There is a slight amount of math and bluffing involved, as well as some player elimination (which only lasts a few minutes). All in all, a fantastic filler or short game to play while waiting for food or drinks.

RATING: 7.2
Super light, and unlike most I love player elimination when it is done well, and it is done really well in this game particularly due to it's speed and as it's played in rounds. The game is quite luck based, with juuuust enough strategy; choosing between two cards sounds like a terrible game, but I admire Love Letter's ability to make that fun and actually have any strategy whatsoever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Love Letter is an extremely light, hilarious game that showcases just how fun sixteen cards can be. I particularly enjoy the player elimination mechanic because it's not obnoxious and adds to the experience. It plays much like a party game--so the more people, the better, simply because they add to story. But the two-player game is really good too, and my husband and I always end up laughing and having a good time competing for the princess' affection. Of course, the gameplay can get a bit repetitive with only sixteen cards, but not as much as you might expect. Also, the cards wear down pretty quickly due to excessive shuffling. But the price is definitely right for a quick filler. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Rating based on just a couple of plays, but I like it a lot so far. Good little filler that can be learned in just a couple of minutes and each round lasts just a few minutes. The interactions between the different cards and the guessing elements make for some funny moments.

Update: Played some more and I'm really liking it. It can go on for just a little too long if you play the recommended number of rounds, but we usually just play a few rounds until we're ready to move on.
A lot of luck involved, a lot of guessing, and just a little bit of deduction and bluffing makes this one a lot of fun.

[b]Player Count Verdict: 3-4[/b]
With two players there's just no reason to play. A player can get eliminated almost immediately, due to the luck of the draw, and then you just start another round where the same thing happens.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Part of my rating is how impressed I am with the design - a lot of fun and flexibility in just 16 cards of only 8 types.

It scales well from 2-4 and even more with two decks. 

Update: I really like this one, but it seems to confound non-gamers more than I would have imagined. Not so much that I won't play it with non-gamers, indeed, I have had good success with it, but both card play and the deduction are novel ideas for people who are not in the hobby and it makes it non-intuitive.



Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 5
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 5
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 5
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 4


Overall - 5

RATING: N/A
Red velvet bag EAG edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[thing=129622][/thing] is a testament to the power of the design: a whole game inside sixteen cards!

It is said that the game lasts about 20 minutes, but ours took about 40 minutes, though I can see that, when everyone knows the cards well (not a difficult task), the play time will severely drop - so 20 minutes is definitely not out of question.

The theme passes nowehere near the actual gameplay: the players represent suitors to the love of the Princess, wanting that their love letters reach her. This isn't easy, since, after the arrest of the Queen, the Princess is bound to be inside the palace, under watch. So the suitors must try to use the Guard, the Handmaid, the Priest, the Baron, the Prince, the Countess and even the King to achieve the their purpose: to win the Princess affection and heart.

Each player has a card in hand and, in his turn, must take another one from the draw pile, then is mandatory to discard one of them, applying its effect. If any player is left without a card in hand (due to the effect of some card), he/she is out of the round. The round ends when only one player has a card in hand, or when the draw pile is empty - in the first case, the player wins outright; in the second case, the player holding the card with the higher number (which, in the theme, represents the person closest to the Princess) is the winner of the round. The number of rounds a player must win in order to be the overall winner varies accordingly to the number of players.

[thing=129622][/thing] is fast, fun and full of decisions to be made - usually not a hard one, so the game suits easily to non-gamers of any sort. For gamers, though, is rather light, so you can't count on a night of [thing=129622][/thing] games. It is an ice-breaker and/or night ender. Álso, be aware that [thing=129622][/thing] isn't a party game: it only accommodates up to 4 players.

A nice game that stays inside a lovely red draw bag. For its price, it was an excellent purchase!

***

My review (in purtuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1017770/love-letter-resenha-em-portugues-review-in-port]here[/url].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favourite fillers, mainly because it's fast and fun and, because it plays so quickly, even getting knocked out by a lucky guess on the first round is more amusing than irritating. There's certainly a strong luck element and there are times when there's only one way to play but I don't find it at all repetitive or boring. Not everybody's cup of tea, I guess, but quite accessible to non-gamers (including kids). Best with 4 players (also plays well with modifications that take it up to 5-6).

RATING: 8.5
A simple deduction/bluffing game to play with families and friends. 
Game time is short. The game is very portable with just 16 cards. This will likely be another game that we can bring along with us when we are outside besides Hive. The other good thing is it is very light!

We have tried the 2-player version and find that it is not as fun as the 4-player version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good:
-Gateway game
-So cheap!
-Competitive without being mean
-Balanced
-Easy, quick, and meaningful decisions
-Solid catch-up mechanic (pick on people in the lead)
-Gets players to react and interact

Bad:
-Theme is terrible.  Red cubes?  Really?!
-Four wins is probably too long 

Overall:
This is a game everyone should have in their collection and is the best filler I've played.  There is a base level of strategy that is accessible to all players which ensure players are almost always on a level playing field.  The game does a great job at making you feel smart because the strategy unravels itself organically as you play.

RATING: 9
Original rating: 7
After 2 years: 9
Great filler game and incredible ratio of gameplay to components. Simple mechanics encourage quick play, including some elements of luck, bluffing, and short & long term strategy (long meaning a minute from now).

Plays fine with 5 even though it's rated to 4. Almost no downtime keeps people engaged. Very few people I know that won't kill time with a game of this while waiting. (And still manages to create good stories when you explain why you did what you did after each round.)

Perfect travel game.

RATING: 8
Short - Portable - 9 - 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sure, this game has plenty of player elimination and is extremely unpredictable with loads of luck. You can easily get eliminated before playing a hand or be forced to reveal your identity through no fault of your own. The game contains only a handful of cards and the art is mediocre at best and resembles famous actors (Baron von Trapp, I am looking at you!). However, with all the shortcomings, this game still shines. It is fun and a hoot with the right folks. Each round takes roughly 10 minutes and even though there is elimination, it rarely matters as everyone is eager to go for the next hand. A huge bang for the buck!

101913: Obtained the original Kanai special edition reprint from AEG because of the art. I like the art, the new box and the cards. I love the new Priestess function but am on the fence with the minister. It does feel cheap losing on the opening round when you get above 12+ on the minister. May have to use the modified rule

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
Elegant and entertaining choose and play game. With just sixteen cards and some wooden bits this game is both gripping and rewarding. It has hooked quite a few non-gamers and a bunch of the old hardcores. Very easy to approach and surprising amount of replayability. Bluff might gain you edge and it is surprising how often you play the wrong one of the two cards you have to choose from. Despite occasional no-win hands this game plays well, has a feel of lightness and elegance and is a looker despite the low price. For anyone who like to spend time with a small bunch of good people.

RATING: 8
A beautifully produced, fantastic little card game that fits in your pocket.  
It's been called a pub game but, depending on who you go to the pub with, you might get a few odd looks at your local after pulling out a scarlet velvet bag with "love letter" embroidered on the side.  
Definitely sleeve your cards however as they'll be getting a lot of handling. Also, do yourself a favor and replace the red cubes with wooden heart tokens from Meeplesource. Nice.

In any case definitely worth the small investment for a game that is easy to teach and quick to play!

RATING: 8
Kanai vs Tempest? Tempest. Overall, both are good games. They are easy to learn and quick to play through. Really enjoyable without breaking a sweat. I picked Tempest over Kanai as it adds more misdirection into the game, effectively increasing the depth of strategy. 

Not an essential game to own, not a highly recommended game to start the hobby with, but a good change of pace for the seasoned gamer.

RATING: 8
Great filler game. Player elimination mechanic is not a problem because of the short rounds and the partial information: the wanting to know what the other players had is enough to keep you interested for the couple of minutes it takes to finish a round. Might be more fun if it were a bit roleplay-ier? The game plays very independently of its flavour.

Possible to add/drop players mid-game (between rounds) but you have to decide what to do about score/handicap in that case.

I like the fact that it can be played with 2 people, but it definitely works best with 4. I kind of wish that it could have even more people because it would be a fun party game, but with the way the role abilities currently work I'm not sure that is feasible. Oh well, I'll just have to enjoy it the way it is.

RATING: 4
I'm a bit puzzled that this seems to have the BGG community so excited.  This simple little guessing game is nothing more than a minimal set of cards with a dash of reading your opponent.  In other words, this is exactly the kinds of stuff that makes BGG disdain mainstream games like [gameid=1115] or [gameid=1917], or in it's purest form, the strangeness that is competitive Rock, Paper, Scissors tournaments.  Sure, it's light, but there's nothing of real interest here.  I could never play again and not miss it.  If you're looking for filler, let's play [gameid=172] or [gameid=16267].

RATING: 5
Rated after two short games, first one with only 1 round, second one with 7 rounds. Ok game, fast, easy and so on, but nothing mind blowing so far.

Updated after third game, three players and to the five points - the game lasted 13 rounds. Now it is clear, that there is a game there, the amount of luck is big, so it is necessary to play multiple rounds. The game is basically a deduction game, because there are so few cards.

Updated after fourth game, two players to seven points. Two player game felt more luck oriented than the three player game, dropped the rating from 6 to 5. Deduction and luck are the strongest elements here.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Everything you've heard about this game is true.  It plays quickly, and allows for some interesting bluffing/hand management decisions during the game.  Once people get into it, they want to play it again right away.  It's well balanced, fun, easy to learn, and so small and portable that almost everyone will want to get one.

It's also nearly impossible to not compare this to Coup, since they're so similar.  They both have weaknesses and strengths compared to one another, and they're also different enough in the way that you have to play them to justify getting them both.  Right now, Coup gets the nod between the two of them, but that won't keep me from getting this one, too.  Once AEG reprints it, that is.

4 plays: 4 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Love Letter is a proof of concept, later expanded in the Lost Legacy series by the same designer.

This game is very simple, and definitely fun! A rating of 7 seems severe for me, for a game I like, but that's only because you should really just be playing its big brother. There's an actual game there, in the form of a desperate, card counting search for a particular card in the deck, balanced with not getting eliminated and also retaining your claim to actually search for it at all.

In Love Letter, you are instead merely trying to hang in there, not get eliminated, and, if it comes to that, have the highest card in your  hand when the deck runs out. A lot of this is chance, but there is some definite strategy, mainly revolving around obfuscating what your actual hand card is. You can play cards that are normally only played when you're holding certain others, to make it look like you are, when you're not. You can watch carefully for someone who always seems to be playing "automatically", as if they don't have a choice between their cards - that usually means they don't, because their hand card is the unplayable Princess, which you should call them out on ASAP before they win. Et cetera. It's amazing what Seiji did with just these few cards. This is, far and away, a fantastic game for families and children, who don't need to know anything special to play well. The theme is universally enjoyable, unless you're insecure in your masculinity so much that red velvet makes you uncomfortable... at which point, just play Batman Love Letter. That's also great.

Then sneak in Lost Legacy when no one is looking.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yes, I do like this one also. Great filler. And when you don't have enough time to play anything else you can always play this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
It's quick, simple and good fun. Very quick to learn, very portable (can carry the whole game rules and all in my back pocket). Can foresee a lot of plays of this as it is very easy to whip out with any crowd as a warm up, filler or anytime really.

It is quick game which is it's main virtue but I actually don't always think it is quick enough and quite like to play with fewer than the recommended rounds, as there is no long term strategy this makes no difference to the play. Have started playing with the rule from Batman variant, this brings it closer to the speed the game feels it should play.

It's rare that I revisit this game, only because of other options, however when I do I'm always impressed by the elegance of this game design.

Number of plays to reach Silver value: 14
Number of plays to reach Gold value: 28

RATING: 7.5
2 - [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/4p/user/Vroenis]4 players[/url].
Teaching: 15 - 25 minutes.
Mastery: 10 - 20 minutes.
Card box (comes in a lovely red felt bag).
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geektag.php?tags=embassy_%26_outpost&username=Vroenis&action=usertags]Embassy_&_Outpost[/url]

Love Letter lives permanently in my [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/survival_kit/user/Vroenis]survival kit[/url], so I've almost always got it on me.

Card game.
Deduction, player elimination (not to worry, rounds resolve quickly).
Light weight - all rules printed on cards!
High player interaction.
Medium-high theme application (high in that there's plenty of opportunity for emergent/meta-narrative).

Super approachable and usually funny once players establish mastery (particularly of dynamics) which happens quite quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
All of the eligible young men (and many of the not-so-young) seek to woo the princess. Unfortunately, she has locked herself in the palace, and you must rely on others to take your romantic letters to her. From a deck with only sixteen cards, each player starts with only one card in hand; one card is removed from play. On a turn, you draw one card, and play one card, trying to expose others and knock them from the game.

RATING: 8
Great game for only being 16 cards.  Does have a bit of luck, which made me hesitant to pick this up, but it's quick and mitigated by multiple rounds.  Rounds are very quick, but there is quite a bit of tension and deduction going on.

It is a terrible game with just 2 players, though, so only great with 3 or 4.

UPDATE: Although a bit more luck based than a lot of the fillers I own. I have to push this up for the sheer number of plays I have managed with my kids. They love it. My 7 year old boy has totally got many of the strategies now and knows what cards he should play when paired up. My 5 year old still has a bit of trouble but sometimes hits his mark all the same! Still, he loves it too.
My rating has dropped a point with subsequent play.There's a heavy dosage of luck which makes it not quite as good as some of my favourite fillers like for sale and high society. Still, it's quicker to play and maybe you should just play first to 3 points, for an uber quick filler. Also, my kids (5&7) love the game and ask daily to play a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
10+ plays, mostly with 3 or 4 players. 

Like: Love Letter packs more gameplay into sixteen cards than many full-fledged board games. You can easily introduce all of the cards in a few minutes, and it only takes a couple rounds for new players to familiarize themselves with all of these cards. This makes Love Letter fantastic as a game to introduce to so-called "non-gamers" since it's quick and easy fun, and the game mechanics themselves can be mastered with little effort. Yet Love Letter retains its charm after many games, which is rare among short games. There is player elimination within the individual rounds of a game, but a round is so fast that there is practically no wait for the next round to start. The same goes for being dealt bad cards in a given round. 

One of the brilliant (yet so simple) aspects of the game which greatly increases its longevity is the removal of one card from the deck in each round. This ensures that a player can never have perfect information in the game unless they have peeked at their opponents' hand using the Priest. Thus bluffing and misdirection are always possible. Aiding this is the fact that the cards are very tightly balanced and designed to give rise to many opportunities for such misdirection. The Countess is a great example; new players will typically only discard her if they have a Prince or King in hand, but then they quickly realize that sometimes it's better to discard the Countess even when they don't necessarily have to, just to mislead other players about their hand. 

Love Letter does an incredible job (with so few cards!) of balancing two paths to victory. You can win by having the highest card remaining at the end of the round, or by knocking all other players out of the round. In my experience, most rounds end with all but one player being knocked out, but the potential for a high card victory is always on everyone's mind and influences most decisions. Because these two different options for success are available, it's surprisingly rare to have a round in which you have no hope of winning.

Dislike: At Love Letter's level of complexity, an 8 is really the highest that I can rate it. With only sixteen cards and "draw one, play one" gameplay, there is not much flexibility within the game's structure for tactics or strategy beyond basic bluffing and deduction. There are rounds (especially if you start with the princess) in which your hand will just play itself, and your only input into the game is to try to mislead everyone else with what you say and how you act. However, the rounds are so quick, and this only tends to happen at most one or two times within a game, so that this is acceptable. What's not so acceptable is that the rapid-fire nature of the rounds (combined with the tiny hands and low card count) means that you will very quickly encounter the majority of the possible game situations (card combinations in hand, opponent's possible cards, etc.). This means that the game's "newness" fades quickly, so you need a good and involved player group to keep Love Letter lively and fun beyond a couple games.

My only other gripe is that it is quite frustrating to get knocked out of a round at the very beginning (before I've had a chance to do anything) by a random Guard guess. However, the speed of the game makes this forgivable.  

Additional note: Because there are so few cards, the cards tend to very quickly show signs of wear which can ruin the game by making certain cards identifiable. I recommend sleeving the cards as quickly as possible.  

Overall: If you like bluffing of any sort, you need to own this game. The best filler game I've played so far. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Light and as much to do with the luck of the draw as anything, but fun. There's more skill involved here than may appear at first, but you have so few turns and it's so easy to get knocked out by a lucky guess that it's never going to be more than a light diversion. It also seems to typically take us double the "official" play time, or even more.

I bought a second copy so I could accommodate more than 4 players. I add 2 Guards, 1 Priest, 1 Baron and 1 Handmaid. It works well for 5 or 6 (winner is first to 3 in both cases). It's not many extra cards, but the speed with which players get knocked out means you don't need  many.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is as good as small, portable filler kind of games get. It's simply brilliant how a game with 16 cards can be so much fun every time. You can learn to play it in minutes, it's setup in seconds and plays so quick you almost can't stop playing. Especially out on the terrace with a beer or two. 

It's a mix of deduction and luck, so everyone can win this game too. It's just hilarious at times when you switch cards only so the next player knows what you have and kills u with a baron for example. Or ending the game with a king and princess, having to switch your hand with the other player and lose. It's just a lot of fun!

The only downside is the theme. It doesn't really appeal to me. Delivering letters to the princess doesn't make sense to me at all when playing the game. But it doesn't affect the gameplay though. Just forget the stupid letters ;)

Update: does lose it's magic after a while though.

RATING: 8
Played this once. The overall feeling was kind of meh. This won some kind of award for innovative play? It doesn't say exactly in the instructions but it's basically, "draw 1, play 1." Last person with cards in their hand (or person with the highest ranking card) wins the round. Repeat until victory point goal is achieved.

** The more you play this, the better it gets. Also helps to play with others who can also find joy in tiny, simple things. It's great fun with the right folks and won't cost much more than a snooty cup of coffee.

RATING: 9
A very quick deduction game for 2-4 players with only 16 cards. Each turn, players draw a card to get a hand of two, then play one of those and use its ability. The person with the highest value card at the end of the game wins, assuming there's more than one person left in.

The main downside is the 2-player game is not as fun. The artwork is attractive and components are good quality. Most importantly, the game is very portable.

RATING: 7.9
[8+],4 ,Recommended with 3-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What a fantastic game for something so simple and tiny; it's a game of just 16 cards for crying out loud!

I ordered the original [company=7552][/company] version after coming home from SPIEL in Essen and playing the game at a Swedish con, and have now learned to not pass by the [company=5885][/company] booth at SPIEL again without buying [person=9495][/person]'s new releases.

Funny enough I got to play [company=396]AEG[/company]'s City-State of Tempest version first and love it! Best of all I'm excited that the two versions of the game differ not only in character graphics and names, but they also contain have slightly different effects and rules. Awesome! This is enough reason to own both versions, right?  :D

Love Letter is absolutely my kind of game. I love games where the ease of play and barrier to entry is very low, but there's a surprising amount of interesting game play once you delve in. I'm also a huge fan of games with poker elements, and by that I mean things such as keeping a poker face, bluffing, double-bluffing, deduction, and meta-gaming. Wonderful game!

I can also report that the [company=396]AEG[/company] edition is gorgeous and of very high quality. If you can get the version in the velvet bag with score counters, nab it immediately! [company=7552][/company]'s original Love Letter which comes in an envelope that looks like an actual love letter is also amazing. To heck with it, just get both versions!

[size=14]Differences between [company=7552][/company] and [company=396]AEG[/company] versions:[/size]

[b]Winning:[/b] In [company=7552][/company]'s original version, you play just one hand, or alternatively until one player has won two hands. In [company=396]AEG[/company]'s version you play until someone has won 7/5/4 rounds for 2/3/4 players, which makes for a much longer game and it evens out the luck more.

[b]Tiebreaker:[/b] There is no tiebreaker in the original [company=7552][/company] version, instead both players win. The rules suggest that you play again, either just with the tied players or everyone involved in the game. In [company=396]AEG[/company]'s version you count up the total amount of all cards played in the game, with the player with the higher total breaking the tie and winning the round. It is therefore important to play all your cards in front of yourself in their version, and the rules actually calls for playing them so all your discards are clearly visible - this makes card counting even easier.

[b]The Minister and Countess[/b] are both rank 7, but very different between the versions. [company=7552][/company]'s Minister loses the game (or round) if you are caught with it and a Princess, General, or Wizard in your hand (i.e. have a hand total of 12 or more). [company=396]AEG[/company]'s Countess only forces you to play her card if you also have the King or Prince in your hand. I prefer how [company=396]AEG[/company]'s Countess keeps you in the game, even though players now have a great shot at guessing your hand, while [company=7552][/company]'s original Minister just ends your turn and feels like it increases the game's luck factor.

[b]The Priestess and Handmaiden[/b] are both rank 4, but their special effects work slightly differently. [company=7552][/company]'s Priestess still allows its player to be targeted , but without effect. However, [company=396]AEG[/company]'s Handmaiden doesn't allow its player to be targeted at all, forcing you to target someone else (including yourself with the Prince if their is no other target). I definitely prefer the implementation of the Priestess to the Handmaiden.

[c][size=10][b]#	Rank	Kanai		AEG[/b]
1	8	Princess	Princess
1	7	Minister	Countess
1	6	General	King
2	5	Wizard		Prince
2	4	Priestess	Handmaid
2	3	Knight		Baron
2	2	Clown		Priest
5	1	Soldier	Guard[/size][/c]

[b]The Princess:[/b] I love how [company=7552][/company]'s version of the game comes with two Princess cards with different art, and even a Prince, just to provide some variety and choice. Kudos!

[b]Card Quality:[/b] Both versions feature poker size cards. I think I prefer [company=7552][/company]'s rather stiff cards, compared to [company=396]AEG[/company]'s cards, while the latter does allow for riffle shuffling, they also get marked up a lot easier, something made worsse by the full color picture of the princess on their backs. Given how important it is for the cards to remain unmarked, you should definitely invest in some premium sleeves regardless of which version you get.


[b]tl;dr:[/b] In summary, I prefer [company=396]AEG[/company]'s version mainly due to how its Countess works compared to [company=7552][/company]'s Minister, rating the former a 10 and the latter a 9. The game is also much better played until someone wins a set number of rounds and with proper tiebreaker rules. I do really like the cute artwork in [company=7552][/company]'s original though, love the alternative Princess and Prince, and prefer the rules of their Priestess to [company=396]AEG[/company]'s Handmaiden.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
When I first heard about this game, a couple of weeks before Spiel, I just ignored it. How could a game with only 16 cards and a couple of tokens, be interesting or at least fun? After Spiel, it seemed like almost everybody picked up a copy of this game. Well, everybody? At least dozens of players of a Dutch forum did. And they were hilarious about this game. I became interested again, but it seemed it was sold out completely. I decided to try to make a print & play copy, as I think the price of the game is too high for what you get.  I bumped along pictures of the 8 different cards there are into play, but I didn’t know the how many of each cards were in the game. I looked further, and suddenly, in the caverns of the Intern, I found it. Started up Photoshop, and created the cards for myself. I translated the text on the cards into Dutch, and printed out the cards on paper sheets. After that, I glued the cards onto cardboard, and created a cardbox. I believed it would be a fun, extra birthday gift for M. To accomplish this, I would have to work fast, as her birthday only last for a couple of hours this day. Luckily for me, she was visiting a soccer match. I managed to fabricate the game in a couple of hours, and I just wrapped it into paper, a couple of minutes before she arrived back home.

M. loved the gift, and we started playing, after I explained the rules to her in less then 1 minute. Basically it comes to this.

    Every player gets one card.
    Top card is out of the game (blind).
    A player takes a card.
    A player plays a card.
    The played card is performed.

Nothing more, nothing less. And it’s fun! Not a deep game at all. This game is about counting cards, bluffing, deduction and guessing. It’s easy to explain, and it plays fast. In a four player game, player who gets 4 tokens first, wins the game. A round will only take a couple of minutes. Or less. It’s possible (at least in a 2-player game it is), that a round is finished, after a player, played just 1 card. As said, this one is plain fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
T
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
So.... here is my ORIGINAL 3/10 rating of the game:

While it's VERY short play time makes it more enjoyable than most ultra-random games, that's not saying much.  Every time we've tried to play this game, I feel like the game is playing me instead.  
First, your "hand" consists of one card only.  So, when you pick up a card and discard a card, you are faced with only 2 choices.  This wouldn't be so bad, but VERY often, you will have a combination of cards from which there IS only one choice.
The card interaction SHOULD be interesting, but when you are never in possession of more than two, and the point of the game dictates that you need to keep the *better* card, you'll always be choosing the lesser one (and if not, it is only because the other card forces you to discard the higher one - I can't remember if that happens in Love Letter or any of its mechanical brethren.  But, in essence, that's how the game always will play out). 
It's boring.  I'm not sure how this game became so popular.  Like other extreme random games, i'd rather just play blackjack.  Why try and change a style game that is already working?

Now, my revised review:

I decided to give this one another try.  I had a very dull day at work and I brought this game with me to see if it would pass the time with my co-worker.  As it happens, we actually had a fun time with it!  I was surprised!
it was still as random, and often as predetermined as when I had tried it before.  However, this time it worked some how....  I think it was mostly because we had a fun time making fun of the outcomes (we aren't too PC when it comes to... our work humor).  We'd swear and curse the cards in quite a vulgar way ("Dirty pervy priest", "whoring countess", "I can't believe your stupid dirty guard snuck into the princess' room!!!!  SUUUUUURE, delivering a letter - like i'd believe that bullshit!" etc).  Somehow, this actually made the game fun to us.  I do not actually think that you should add vulgarity to make a game fun, but - hey - if it makes you laugh and no one is being hurt doing so, I condone a certain crudeness among friends.  
I can't say that it is a game that will come out often.  I won't really recommend it.  But it was good for some laughs, so i'll give it that.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Probably our favorite hidden identities game. Plays really quick, and there are few better feelings than guessing if your opponent has the Handmaiden/Shugenja before they can protect themselves on the first turn. Ahh the little things in life.

RATING: 8
Great game that gets better with more people. A bit of luck is needed but a person that pays attention has the highest chance of winning. There are definite giveaways at what each person has depending on how they play their hand. So, the better you are at remembering and deducing, the better you will be at this game.

RATING: 8
Interesting, quick, little filler. I like the art style, especially the female guards, and the game play is much deeper than you'd expect in such a simple little game. It's not my favorite filler, but it is a good one.
